revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Jabbar Collins | image = Jabbarcollins.jpg | image_size = 147px | caption = Jabbar Collins | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1972|07|08}} | birth_place = {{nowrap|[[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S.}} | nationality = United States | known_for = Wrongful conviction }}
'''Jabbar Collins''' (born July 8, 1972) is a wrongfully-convicted American man who served 16 years for a crime he did not commit. He was convicted of [[Murder#Degrees of murder|second-degree murder]] following the February 1994 death of Orthodox Rabbi Abraham Pollack in [[Williamsburg, Brooklyn]].<ref name="NYT10">{{cite news|first1=Stephanie|last1=Clifford|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/20/nyregion/jabbar-collins-wrongfully-convicted-man-reaches-10-million-settlement-with-new-york-city.html|title=Exonerated Man Reaches $10 Million Deal With New York City|last=|first=|date=19 August 2014|work=New York Times|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref> Police charged 20-year-old Collins, who lived in a nearby housing project, with the murder. He was then sentenced by a jury in March 1995 to 34-years-to-life, sixteen of which he served.<ref name="UMIC">{{Cite web|url=https://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/Pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=3115|title=Jabbar Collins - National Registry of Exonerations|website=www.law.umich.edu|access-date=2018-07-31}} </ref>
In 2010, Collins was [[Exoneration|exonerated]] after a key witness recanted. The case settled in 2014 for $13 million. It exposed questionable policies under the former Brooklyn district attorney, [[Charles J. Hynes]], and his right-hand man, Michael F. Vecchione.<ref name="NYDN">{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/opinion/ny-oped-prosecutors-arent-above-the-law-20180726-story.html|title=Prosecutors aren't above the law: Gov. Cuomo must sign legislation creating an oversight commission|last=Block|first=Frederic|work=NY Daily News|access-date=2018-07-31}}</ref><ref name="NYT13">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/15/nyregion/under-fire-brooklyn-deputy-prosecutor-will-retire.html|title=Under Fire, Brooklyn Deputy Prosecutor Will Retire|last=Yee|first=Vivian|access-date=2018-07-31}}</ref>
The case has been used by the [[Frederic Block|Honorable Frederic Block]] in support of a bill for the nation’s first Commission on Prosecutorial Conduct.<ref name="NYDN"/> Said bill is pending approval{{when|date=October 2018}} by [[Andrew Cuomo|Governor Andrew Cuomo]].
==Background==
Jabbar Collins was raised in [[Brooklyn|Brooklyn, New York]].<ref name="NYP14">{{Cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2014/08/19/man-who-spent-16-years-behind-bars-gets-10m-for-wrongful-conviction/|title=Man who spent 16 years behind bars gets $10M for wrongful conviction|date=2014-08-19|work=New York Post|access-date=2018-07-31}}</ref> At the time of the murder, he lived in a nearby housing project within the vicinity of the crime scene.<ref name="UMIC">{{Cite web|url=https://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/Pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=3115|title=Jabbar Collins - National Registry of Exonerations|website=www.law.umich.edu|access-date=2018-07-31}} </ref> A father of three,<ref name="NYTV"/> Collins was not able to finish high school but nonetheless earned a high school equivalency diploma. He had been enrolled in college classes before his arrest.<ref name="WSJ">{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/jabber-collins-and-new-york-state-reach-settlement-in-wrongful-conviction-case-for-3-million-1405009263|title=Jabbar Collins Settles Wrongful Conviction Suit for $3 Million|last=Gardiner|first=Sean|date=2014-07-10|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-07-31|issn=0099-9660}}</ref>
Collins identifies as a Christian.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.ny1.com/nyc/all-boroughs/inside-city-hall/2017/09/16/jabbar-collins-wrongfully-convicted-interview-work-help-others-wrongfully-convicted#|title=Jabbar Collins: Wrongfully convicted, now helping others|access-date=2018-07-31}}</ref>
==Murder of Abraham Pollack==
Rabbi Abraham Pollack was fatally shot in a failed robbery attempt while collecting rent in a Brooklyn apartment building in which he served as landlord.<ref name="WSJ"/> Those who knew him describe him as a devoted husband and father of nine who “treated everyone fairly” and “didn’t hassle you” about late rent. His generosity and fairness also extended to his workers; Pollack had allowed the janitor, a formerly homeless man, to live in the building’s basement in exchange for assisting the superintendent.<ref name="JWT">{{Cite news|url=https://jewishweek.timesofisrael.com/twenty-years-on-second-thoughts-about-chasids-killer/|title=Twenty Years On, Second Thoughts About Chasid’s Killer|access-date=2018-07-31|last1=Winston|first1=Hella|work=Times of Israel}}</ref>
On a Sunday in early February 1994, Rabbi Pollack was shot to death at the age of thirty-five. The building superintendent witnessed the crime and ran to get assistance from the janitor, who intervened during the attack and was shot and seriously injured.
Approximately two weeks after Rabbi Pollack’s murder, the janitor spoke to detectives and an assistant district attorney. He revealed that he had cut the perpetrator of the crime on his right side with a knife while intervening during the crime.<ref name="JWT"/>
Curiously, Collins did not exhibit any injury on his side when he voluntarily went to the 90th Precinct for a police interview twelve days following the murder.
Although both the building super and janitor were eyewitnesses to the murder of Rabbi Pollack, neither witness positively identified Collins as the perpetrator in a police lineup. Furthermore, Collins has a strong alibi placing him away from the scene of the crime.<ref name="JWT"/>
Early police reports indicate that a few witnesses had stated that the perpetrator was a local drug dealer who had been under recent investigation, alongside his brother, for another robbery. In the hour following the crime, the superintendent was shown photos of this drug dealer and his brother, whom he said resembled the man who murdered Rabbi Pollack. Another police report also states that that one of the brothers has a scar “on [the] stomach area” — the same area where the janitor had cut the perpetrator with a knife.<ref name="JWT"/>
Regardless of the fact that there was incriminating evidence against other suspects, the police continued to focus their investigation on Collins after they had received an anonymous phone call implicating him. The case built against Collins relied substantially on three witnesses, who were heavy drug users and whose accounts were not consistent with those of actual eyewitnesses.<ref name="JWT"/>
==Trial==
Collins was convicted in March 1995 after two witnesses testified to seeing him flee the crime scene. Another witness claimed that Collins had revealed his plans to rob Pollack as he was collecting rent.<ref name="WSJ"/>
===Verdict and sentencing===
Collins was sentenced to 34-years-to-life in prison for murder in the second-degree.
However, according to court documents, police were aware of [[Exculpatory evidence|exculpatory information]] pertaining to Collins.<ref name="JWT"/>
==Appeal== Sure of his innocence, Collins began fighting his conviction while at the [[Green Haven Correctional Facility]], a maximum security state prison. Upon requesting documents through the [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|Freedom of Information Act]], Collins soon realized that some of these materials had not been provided to his trial lawyer at the time of his conviction. He decided to contact the witnesses whose testimonies implicated him in the murder of Rabbi Pollack. Collins soon found discrepancies in their stories and realized that the men had "received favorable treatment on pending cases in exchange for their testimony."<ref name="WSJ"/> Witness admitted to having been enticed or threatened by the prosecution.<ref name="NYT10"/> One of these witnesses later testified at a hearing that when he tried to recant his statement implicating Collins before trial, a prosecutor had threatened to hit him with a coffee table.<ref name="WSJ"/> Eventually, all three witnesses ultimately recanted their statements.
Collins also uncovered important [[prosecutorial misconduct]] in that a prosecutor did not turn over potentially exculpatory evidence to the defense. Ultimately, the city admitted to the withholding of this exculpatory evidence at the time of the 1995 trial, conceding that Collins’ conviction and sentencing "resulted from violations of his [[Constitutional right|constitutional rights]]."<ref name="NYT10"/>
After failing to receive relief in state court, Collins filed a petition for [[habeas corpus]] in federal court and enlisted the help of attorney Joel B. Rudin.<ref name="NYT10"/> The defense asked for an order prohibiting [[New trial|retrial]] because of the gross misconduct. Following a one-day evidentiary hearing, the Kings County District Attorney’s Office decided not to oppose that outcome, perhaps because the prosecution witnesses were too compromised to retry the case. Even so, the office continued to allege that Collins was guilty.<ref name="UMIC">{{Cite web|url=https://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/Pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=3115|title=Jabbar Collins - National Registry of Exonerations|website=www.law.umich.edu|access-date=2018-07-31}} </ref>
In June 2010, officials at the Brooklyn District Attorney's Office, who had previously stated that they would retry Collins, [[Motion (legal)#To dismiss|dismissed]] the case. A representative said at the time that the office still believed Collins to be the killer.<ref name="WSJ"/>
===Settlement=== [[Settlement (litigation)|Settlement]] was reached in July 2014. At the behest of Judge Frederic Block, who urged city and state officials to settle Collins’ wrongful conviction lawsuit before going to trial,<ref name="WSJ"/> the matter settled for $3 million under the Unjust Conviction Act.<ref name="NYT10"/>
On the topic of this agreement, Collins’ attorney, Joel B. Rudin, commented, “Three million dollars is a lot of money, but it is a fraction of what Jabbar Collins is entitled to for 15 horrendous years in a maximum security state prison. We look forward now to concentrating totally on his much larger claim for damages against New York City.”<ref name="WSJ"/>
==Allegations of prosecutorial misconduct== ===Charles Hynes=== As of July 2018, Collins is also suing former Brooklyn District Attorney Charles Hynes, former members of his office, and New York Police Department detectives for civil violations in federal court.<ref name="WSJ"/>
This lawsuit follows [[Deposition (law)|depositions]] conducted by Collins’ lawyer, Joel B. Rudin, in the murder case. During a December 2010 deposition, Hynes reportedly stated that when he ordered the case dismissed, he no longer believed that Collins was guilty and that there was no evidence connecting him to the murder. He also stated under questioning that there was “a failure of ethical responsibility by someone involved in the case.”<ref name="WSJ"/>
===Michael Vecchione=== The case also brought to question the conduct of former Assistant District Attorney Michael F. Vecchione, who is renowned as an aggressive prosecutor who has overseen many high profile cases and co-author of the book, Friends of the Family.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/crime/new-book-friends-family-mafia-cops-claims-fbi-hogged-glory-article-1.361032|title=New book, 'Friends of the Family,' on Mafia cops claims FBI hogged the glory|last=Marzulli|first=John|work=NY Daily News|access-date=2018-07-31}}</ref> According to a New York Times article, Collins accused Vecchione of “playing God” in his threats against witnesses, elicitation of inaccurate testimonies, and withholding of exculpatory evidence. The misconduct which Collins believed deprived him of a fair trial, included the elicitation of a testimony from Angel Santos, one of the three witnesses who testified in the 1995 trial. In his testimony at the aborted habeas corpus hearing, Santos recounted [[coercion]] by Vecchione at the initial trial, stating that he was not only threatened but also held in jail for a week, until he testified.<ref name="NYTV"/>
The settlement spared the testimony of Vecchione who, in 2006, had signed a sworn affidavit dispeling notions of use of force or threats in obtaining witness testimonies.<ref name="NYTV">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/09/nyregion/09vecchione.html|title=Brooklyn Prosecutor Drops Case Against Man Held in Murder|work=New York Times|last=Sulzberger|first=A. G.|access-date=2018-07-31}}</ref> Highly criticized for his conduct in this case by District Attorney Charles Hynes’ successor [[Kenneth P. Thompson|Kenneth Thompson]], though not officially related, Vecchione retired in December 2013.<ref name="NYT13">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/15/nyregion/under-fire-brooklyn-deputy-prosecutor-will-retire.html|title=Under Fire, Brooklyn Deputy Prosecutor Will Retire|last=Yee|first=Vivian|access-date=2018-07-31}}</ref>
===Judicial significance: Bill for Commission on Prosecutorial Conduct===
According to a New York Daily News opinions editorial, [[Frederic Block|Federal Judge Frederic Block]] (who served in the settled civil case) was troubled by the lack of accountability in this matter.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/b-klyn-da-charles-hynes-hot-seat-wrongful-conviction-article-1.1203342|title=Brooklyn DA Charles Hynes in hot seat for protecting prosecutor who imprisoned innocent man|last=Marzulli|first=John|work=NY Daily News|access-date=2018-07-31}}</ref> While he ruled that the city could be held liable, he was forced to dismiss the claims against the prosecutor and the district attorney of [[prosecutorial immunity]].
Block notes, as of July 30, 2018, the state and city taxpayers have paid $13 million in settlements. Despite his "egregious behavior," the prosecutor has neither been forced to pay for the settlement or face any punishment.<ref name="NYDN"/> Block maintains that it is not uncommon for wrongful conviction cases across New York to stem from “a whole array of prosecutorial misconduct” yet simultaneously cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars “for the many years the innocent defendants spent in jail.” Prosecutors, he notes, have curiously remained largely unscathed.<ref name="NYDN"/>
==Personal life== While in prison, both of Collins’ grandmothers passed away.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.ny1.com/nyc/all-boroughs/inside-city-hall/2017/09/16/jabbar-collins-wrongfully-convicted-interview-work-help-others-wrongfully-convicted#|title=Jabbar Collins: Wrongfully convicted, now helping others|access-date=2018-07-31}}</ref>
While incarcerated, Collins spent eight years helping his fellow inmates by acting as a legal research instructor. Since being released from prison, Collins has worked as a legal analyst at the Law Offices of Joel B. Rudin. He currently works as a legal analyst for Horizon Research Services<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/jabbar-collins-62ba9830/|title=Jabbar Collins|last=|first=|date=|website=Linkedin|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name=":1" />
In 2017, Collins appeared on NY1 to discuss wrongful convictions with his legal partner Rita Dave.<ref name=":0" />
==References== {{Reflist}}

Leach | nickname = Leachy,<ref name="MCC University profile">{{cite web |url=http://www.mccuniversities.org/cardiff-glamorgan/player-profiles/jack-leach,215,PP.html |title=Jack Leach Profile |publisher=MCC Universities |accessdate=30 April 2013 }}</ref> The Nut<ref>https://www.ecb.co.uk/news/645649/sweet-as-a-nut-jack-leach-s-journey-to-england-s-test-squad</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1991|6|22|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Taunton]], [[Somerset]], England | heightft = | heightinch = | heightm = | batting = Left-handed | bowling = [[Left-arm orthodox spin|Slow left-arm orthodox]] | role = Spin bowler | international = true | internationalspan = 2018–present | testdebutdate = 30 March | testdebutyear = 2018 | testdebutagainst = New Zealand | lasttestdate = 23 November | lasttestyear = 2018 | lasttestagainst = Sri Lanka | testcap = 684 | club1 = [[Somerset County Cricket Club|Somerset]] | year1 = {{nowrap|2010–present}} | clubnumber1 = 17 | club2 = [[Cardiff MCC University|Cardiff MCCU]] | year2 = 2011–2012 | club3 = [[Marylebone Cricket Club]] (MCC) | year3 = 2017 | columns = 3 | column1 = [[Test cricket|Test]] | matches1 = 4 | runs1 = 55 | bat avg1 = 9.16 | 100s/50s1 = 0/0 | top score1 = 16 | deliveries1 = 1,162 | wickets1 = 20 | bowl avg1 = 24.90 | fivefor1 = 1 | tenfor1 = 0 | best bowling1 = 5/83 | catches/stumpings1 = 2/– | column2 = [[First-class cricket|FC]] | matches2 = 70 | runs2 = 866 | bat avg2 = 12.02 | 100s/50s2 = 0/2 | top score2 = 66 | deliveries2 = 13,529 | wickets2 = 236 | bowl avg2 = 25.66 | fivefor2 = 17 | tenfor2 = 3 | best bowling2 = 8/85 | catches/stumpings2 = 24/– | column3 = [[List A cricket|LA]] | matches3 = 16 | runs3 = 22 | bat avg3 = 7.33 | 100s/50s3 = 0/0 | top score3 = 18 | deliveries3 = 824 | wickets3 = 21 | bowl avg3 = 30.52 | fivefor3 = 0 | tenfor3 = n/a | best bowling3 = 3/7 | catches/stumpings3 = 9/– | date = 26 November | year = 2018 | source = https://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/player/455524.html ESPNCricinfo }} '''Matthew Jack Leach''' (born 22 June 1991), known as '''Jack Leach''', is an English [[cricket]]er who plays for [[Somerset County Cricket Club]] and [[England cricket team|England]]. A spin bowler, he bowls [[left-arm orthodox spin]], and bats left-handed. He made his [[First-class cricket|first-class]] debut for [[Cardiff MCC University]] against Somerset in 2012 before making his debut for Somerset in the tour match against the [[South Africa national cricket team|South Africans]] later in the summer.
==Early life and education== Leach was born in [[Taunton]], England on 22 June 1991, and attended Trinity School, [[Bishop Fox's School]] and [[Richard Huish College, Taunton|Richard Huish College]] all in Taunton.<ref name="Cricinfo profile">{{cite web |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/england/content/player/455524.html |title=Jack Leach Profile |publisher=ESPNcricinfo |accessdate=30 April 2013 }}</ref> He used to be employed to park trolleys at a branch of [[Sainsbury's]] supermarket in Taunton.<ref name="Maiden Five-wicket haul">{{cite news |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/county-cricket-2013/content/story/632900.html |last=Dobell |first=George |title=Warwickshire last pair thwart Somerset |publisher=ESPNcricinfo |date=28 April 2013 |accessdate=30 April 2013 }}</ref> At the age of 14, Leach was diagnosed with [[Crohn's disease]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/cricket/46046486 |title=Jack Leach on England, DJ-ing at Jos Buttler's wedding, Crohn's & trolleys |work=BBC Sport |accessdate=2 November 2018}}</ref>
==Cricket career== Leach graduated from the [[Somerset County Cricket Club]] academy in the summer of 2010,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.somersetcountycc.co.uk/player/jack-leach/ |title=Jack Leach – Squad |publisher=Somerset County Cricket Club |accessdate=30 April 2013 }}</ref> prior to signing a professional contract with Somerset. Leach represented [[Dorset County Cricket Club]] in the 2010 [[Minor Counties Cricket Championship]], and bowled his side to victory in the final against [[Lincolnshire County Cricket Club|Lincolnshire]] taking 6/21 in their second innings.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/266/266298.html |title=Dorset v Lincolnshire in 2010 |publisher=CricketArchive |accessdate=30 April 2013 }}</ref> Leach completed his degree at the [[University of Wales Institute, Cardiff]] in sports coaching.<ref name="MCC University profile"/> Whilst attending university Leach represented [[Cardiff MCC University|Cardiff MCCU]] in 2011 and 2012 making his first-class debut against his county side Somerset in March 2012, bowling 41 overs but failing to take a wicket as Somerset amassed 642/3[[Declaration and forfeiture|d]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/542465.html |title=Somerset v Cardiff MCCU at Taunton, 31 March – 2 April, 2012 |publisher=ESPNcricinfo |accessdate=30 April 2013 }}</ref>
Leach made his Somerset debut in a two-day match against the [[South African cricket team in England in 2012|touring]] [[South Africa national cricket team|South Africans]] in July 2012, claiming the prized wicket of [[Hashim Amla]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/england-v-south-africa-2012/content/story/571791.html |title=Duminy finds valuable form ahead of Tests |last=Moonda |first=Firdose |publisher=ESPNcricinfo |date=10 July 2012 |accessdate=30 April 2013 }}</ref> He made his first-class debut for Somerset in the [[2012 County Championship]] match against [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]] in August 2012,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/Spinner-Leach-lined-Somerset-debut-Liverpool/story-16623597-detail/story.html |title=Spinner Leach is lined up for Somerset debut in Liverpool |publisher=The Bristol Post |date=1 August 2012 |accessdate=30 April 2013 }}</ref> the rain affected match finished as a draw with Leach claiming [[Kyle Hogg]] as his maiden first-class wicket.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/county-cricket-2012/content/story/575419.html |title=Prince turns match on its head |last=Hodgson |first=Myles |publisher=ESPNcricinfo |date=3 August 2012 |accessdate=30 April 2013 }}</ref> Further opportunities in the first team were limited for the rest of the 2012 season with the signing of Pakistani spinner [[Abdur Rehman (cricketer, born 1980)|Abdur Rehman]], and Leach only featured in one further County Championship match and three matches in the [[2012 Clydesdale Bank 40]], but ended the season ninth in the national first-class averages with 12 wickets at 18.83 runs apiece.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.somersetcountycc.co.uk/2012/09/jacks-off-to-play-grade-cricket-in-brisbane/ |title=Jack's off to play Grade Cricket in Brisbane |publisher=Somerset County Cricket Club |date=25 September 2012 |accessdate=30 April 2013 }}</ref> Leach spent the 2012–13 winter playing [[grade cricket]] for [[Valley District Cricket Club]] in [[Brisbane]], Australia, helping his side to win the T20 competition.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.somersetcountycc.co.uk/2013/03/jack-leach-aiming-for-championship-opener-against-durham/ |title=Jack Leach aiming for Championship opener against Durham |publisher=Somerset County Cricket Club |date=24 March 2013 |accessdate=30 April 2013 }}</ref>
Leach returned to Somerset for pre-season on a summer contract and played his first [[2013 County Championship|Championship]] game of the season against [[Warwickshire County Cricket Club|Warwickshire]] due to an injury to first choice spinner [[George Dockrell]]; he took his maiden five-wicket haul in the second innings, with 24 of his 44 overs being maidens.<ref name="Maiden Five-wicket haul"/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/cricket/22339873 |title=Jack Leach: Somerset spinner frustrated by Bears draw |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 April 2013 |accessdate=30 April 2013 }}</ref>
==International career== On 14 February 2018, while playing for the [[England Lions (cricket team)|England Lions]] against [[West Indies A]], Leach achieved match figures of 8-110: in doing so, he beat the previous best figures by an England Lions spinner ([[Graeme Swann]]'s 8-156).<ref>{{cite web|title=Jack Leach claims best figures by England Lions spinner during defeat to West Indies A|url=http://www.skysports.com/cricket/news/12173/11250662/jack-leach-claims-best-figures-by-england-lions-spinner-during-defeat-to-west-indies-a|website=Sky Sports|accessdate=14 February 2018|date=14 February 2018}}</ref>
On 16 March 2018 he was called up to England's [[Test cricket|Test]] squad for the [[English cricket team in New Zealand in 2017–18|tour of New Zealand]] as an injury replacement for [[Mason Crane]].<ref>https://www.telegraph.co.uk/cricket/2018/03/16/england-call-jack-leach-replace-injured-mason-crane/</ref> He made his debut in the second Test in [[Christchurch]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/1115781.html|title=2nd Test, England tour of Australia and New Zealand at Christchurch, Mar 30 - Apr 3 2018|work=ESPN Cricinfo|accessdate=30 March 2018}}</ref>
In an unusual circumstance, with 1 over left to play during [[English cricket team in Sri Lanka in 2018–19|a Test match against Sri Lanka]] on 15 November 2018, Jack Leach opened England's innings as a [[nightwatchman (cricket)|nightwatchman]], surviving till stumps. He was dismissed for 1 off 11 balls the next morning.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/series/18602/commentary/1140386/sri-lanka-vs-england-2nd-test-eng-in-sl-2018-19|title=2nd Test, England tour of Sri Lanka at Kandy, Nov 14-18 2018|work=ESPN Cricinfo|accessdate=16 November 2018}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of people diagnosed with Crohn's disease]]

revision.comment: added information to disappearance and biography
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Jacobo Grinberg | birth_name = Jacobo Grinberg-Zylberbaum | birth_date = {{Birth date|1946|12|12}} | birth_place = [[Mexico City|Mexico City, Mexico]] | disappeared_date = {{Disappeared date and age|1994|12|8|1946|12|12}} | disappeared_status = {{Missing for|1994|12|8}} | nationality = [[Mexicans|Mexican]] }} '''Jacobo Grinberg-Zylberbaum''' is/was a Mexican neurophysiologist, writer and psychologist. He studied Mexican [[shamanism]], Eastern disciplines, [[meditation]], and [[telepathy]] through the [[scientific method]]. He wrote more than 50 books about these subjects.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=|title=Jacobo Grinberg, desaparecido|last=Cherem S.|first=Silvia|date=September 18, 1995|work=Reforma|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> Jacobo disappeared in December 1994.
== Biography == Jacobo Grinberg-Zylberbaum was born in [[Mexico City]] in 1946. Grinberg decided to study the human mind when he was 12 years old, after his mother died from a stroke.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://pijamasurf.com/2011/08/jacobo-grinberg-su-genial-obra-y-su-misteriosa-desaparicion/|title=Jacobo Grinberg: su genial obra y su misteriosa desaparición|last=Barros del Villar|first=Javier|date=February 8, 2011|website=Pijama Surf|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> He studied [[psychology]] at the Science Faculty of [[National Autonomous University of Mexico|UNAM]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=March 10, 2010|title=Dr. Jacobo Grinberg, Investigador de la conciencia desaparecido misteriosamente|url=http://diariojudio.com/comunidad-judia-mexico/dr-jacobo-grinberg-investigador-de-la-conciencia-desaparecido-misteriosamente/15800/#|journal=Diario Judío|volume=|pages=}}</ref> In 1970, he went to [[New York City]] to study [[psychophysiology]] at the Brain Research Institute. He earned a [[Ph.D.]] at the [[E. Roy John]] Laboratory.<ref name=":1" /> His Ph.D. focuses on the electrophysiological effects of geometric stimuli on the human brain.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://www.jacobogrinberg.com/|title=jacobo|website=jacobo|language=es|access-date=2018-12-01}}</ref>
When he went back to [[Mexico]], he founded a laboratory of psychophysiology at the [[Universidad Anáhuac]]. He installed another laboratory of this kind in UNAM in the late 1970s. He founded the Instituto Nacional para el Estudio de la Conciencia (INPEC) in 1987,<ref name=":0" /> financed by UNAM and CONACYT. Jacobo published several of his books through INPEC.<ref name=":1" /> Grinberg wrote more than 50 books about brain activity, [[witchcraft]], [[shamanism]], [[telepathy]], and [[meditation]].<ref name=":0" />
Jacobo tended to put his reputation as a scientist in danger when he tried to use the scientific method in shamanism studies.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Attie|first=Leah Bella|date=December 17, 1995|title=No debemos olvidar|url=|journal=Reforma|volume=|pages=}}</ref> He combined the two in his professional work, always trying to understand the “magic world.”<ref name=":0" /> It is said that while his work exhibited the scientific basis for telepathy, it was often rejected by fellow scientists. <ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/the-secret-behind-doctor-grinberg-film-mexico#/|title=THE SECRET BEHIND DOCTOR GRINBERG|website=Indiegogo|access-date=2018-12-01}}</ref>
Comments by Guerzon - you could provide information about a specific book or other research/accomplishments he's known for - so far so good! == Disappearance == Since December 8, 1994, Jacobo Grinberg has been missing. On December 12, his family prepared a party for him to celebrate his 48th birthday, but he did not show up.<ref name=":0" /> It was common for him to make spontaneous travels or just not answer his phone for days, which is why his disappearance did not seem odd to his family in the beginning.<ref name=":0" /> There are many conspiracies surrounding Jacobo's disappearance. It has been speculated that NASA or the CIA kidnapped him after the U.S military became interested in his research on the relationship between metaphysical worlds and humans and tried to seize his work.
<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" />
== The Sintergy Theory == Grinberg's sintergy theory states that there is a continuous space of energy and the common human can only perceive a part of it. The result of this process is what everyone understand as "reality."<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Martínez González|first=Roberto|date=2007|title=Lo que el chamanismo nos dejó: Cien años de estudios chamánicos en México y Mesoamérica|url=|journal=Anales de Antropología|volume=|pages=}}</ref> This theory tries to answer the question of the creation of the experience. It is based on years of brain experiments and consciousness studies.<ref name=":3" /> The book where it is mentioned, "El Cerebro Consciente," was translated into seven languages.<ref name=":2" />
Comments by Guerzon - what is Grinberg's expertise or contributions about the Sintergy Theory ==See also== *[[List of people who disappeared mysteriously]]
== Bibliography == * ''La Experiencia Interna''; Trillas, México 1975. INPEC 1987 * ''La Construcción de la Realidad''; Trillas, México 1975. INPEC 1987 * ''Las Creaciones de la Existencia''; Trillas, México 1976 * ''El Vehículo de las Transformaciones''; Trillas, México. 1976 * ''Más allá de los Lenguajes''; Trillas, México 1976 * ''Psicofisiología del Aprendizaje''; Trillas, México 1976 * ''Nuevos Principios de Psicología Fisiológica''; Trillas, México 1976 * ''El Despertar de la Conciencia''; Trillas, México 1978 * ''Los Fundamentos de la Experiencia''; Trillas, México 1978 * ''El Cerebro Consciente''; Trillas, México 1979 * ''Bases Psicofisiológicas de la Memoria y el Aprendizaje I: Fase de la Memoria''; Trillas, México 1979 * ''Bases Psicofisiológicas de la Memoria y el Aprendizaje II: La Localización de la Memoria''; Trillas, México 1979 * ''Bases Psicofisiológicas de la Memoria y el Aprendizaje III: Naturaleza de la Memoria''; Trillas, México 1980 * ''Bases Psicofisiológicas de la Percepción Visual I: Estructuras Subcorticales''; Trillas, México 1981 * ''El Espacio y la Conciencia''; Trillas, México 1981 * ''Las Manifestaciones del Ser I: Pachita''; EDAMEX, México 1981 * ''Las Manifestaciones del Ser II: Cuauhtemoctzin''; EDAMEX, México 1982 * ''La Luz Angelmática''; EDAMEX, México 1983. INPEC 1988 * ''En Busca del Ser''; INPEC, México 1987 – 1990 * ''Correlativos Electrofisiológicos de la Comunicación Humana''. Facultad de Medicina. UNAM Tesis Doctoral 1987 * ''Meditación Auto alusiva''; INPEC, México 1987 – 1990 * ''Retorno a la Luz''; SEP, México 1987 * ''La Expansión del Presente''; INPEC, México 1988 * ''Creation of Experience''; INPEC, México 1988 * ''Psicofisiología del Poder''; INPEC, México 1988 * ''Cantos de Ignorancia Iluminada'';. INPEC, México 1988 * ''Los Chamanes de México I: Psicología Autóctona Mexicana''; Alpa Corral, México 1987. INPEC 1990 * ''Los Chamanes de México II: Misticismo Indígena''; Alpa Corral, México. 1987 * ''Los Chamanes de México III: Pachita''; INPEC, México 1989. Heptada Madrid España 1990 * ''Los Chamanes de México IV: La Cosmovisión de los Chamanes''; INPEC, México 1988 * ''Los Chamanes de México V: El Cerebro y los Chamanes''; INPEC, México 1989 * ''Los Chamanes de México VI: La Voz del Ver''; INPEC, México 1989 * ''Los Chamanes de México VII: El Doble''; INPEC, México 1990 * ''La Creación de la Experiencia''; Los libros del Comienzo, Madrid España. 1990 * ''Técnicas de Meditación Trascendente''; Heptada Madrid España 1990 * ''La Conquista del Templo''; Heptada, Madrid España 1990 * ''La Meditación''; INPEC, México 1991 * ''Fluir en El sin yo''; INPEC, México 1991 * ''La Teoría Sintérgica''; INPEC, México 1991 * ''La Batalla por el Templo''; INPEC, México 1991 * ''La Fuerza Vital del Cielo Anterior'';. INPEC, México 1991 * ''El Prototipo''; INPEC, México 1991 * ''Recontre avec les Chamans du Mexique''; Editions Le Mail, Aix en Provence, Francia 1994 * ''El Sabor de la Iluminación''; Sirio 1994 * ''El YO como idea''; INPEC-UNAM. México, 1994.

revision.text:
'''Jakub Polák''' (1 September 1952 – 25 September 2012) was a Czech [[anarchism|anarchist]]<ref>Nadace M. J. Stránského, ''The New Presence'' (1998).</ref> and [[anti-racism]] activist.<ref name="CPA-obit">Czech Press Agency, Gwendolyn Albert (transl.), [http://www.romea.cz/english/index.php?id=detail&detail=2007_3632 "Czech anarchist, advocate of Romani people's rights, has passed away"], Romea.cz, Sept. 26, 2012.</ref> Polák was involved particularly in [[Romani people|Roma]] rights and [[squatting|squatter]]s' rights issues.<ref name="CNA-obit">Czech News Agency, [http://praguemonitor.com/2012/09/27/czech-anarchist-movement-doyen-polak-dies "Czech Anarchist Movement Doyen Polak Dies"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102142505/http://praguemonitor.com/2012/09/27/czech-anarchist-movement-doyen-polak-dies |date=2012-11-02 }}, Sept. 27, 2012.</ref>
Polák was born in [[Karlovy Vary]] and grew up in [[czechoslovak Socialist Republic|Marxist–Leninist Czechoslovakia]].<ref name="CNA-obit" /> He became a dissident in his teens, when he became involved in the [[Prague Spring|Prague Spring of 1968]], and as a consequence he was not permitted to attend university.<ref name="CPA-obit" /> He took part in various dissident and underground movement activities.<ref name="CNA-obit" /> He was a co-founder of the 1989 [[Strike action|strike]] committee that led to the [[Velvet Revolution]].<ref name="CPA-obit" /> He was also involved with the Czech branch of the [[Movement for Civil Society]].<ref name="roth">Stephen Roth Institute, ''Antisemitism Worldwide 2000/1'', University of Nebraska Press, 2002, p.186, citing ''Prague Post'', April 25-May 1, 2001.</ref>
After the fall of the [[Eastern Bloc]], Polák openly founded numerous [[anarchism|anarchist]] organizations and publications.<ref name="CPA-obit" /> He joined the "Levá alternativa" ("LA"; transl. "Left Alternative"), eventually becoming a member of its anarchist wing.<ref name="CPA-obit" /> The group split, with the anarchist LA becoming the Československé anarchistické sdružení (ČAS; transl. Czechoslovak Anarchist Association).<ref name="CPA-obit" /> In 1991, Polák and others from ČAS founded the ''[[A-Kontra]]'' magazine, which became the central organ of the Czech anarchist movement in the 1990s and early 2000s.<ref name="CPA-obit" /> Polák remained involved with ''A-Kontra'' until his death, working as editor-in-chief with the magazine.<ref name="CNA-obit" /><ref name="roth" />
Polák was involved in numerous anti-racist organizations and activities. He worked as "attorney-in-fact" with numerous victims of racist and neo-Nazi attacks, including in the case of [[Tibor Danihel]], a victim of a 1993 attack by [[White power skinhead|racist skinheads]] in [[Písek]], [[South Bohemian Region|South Bohemia]],<ref name="CNA-obit" /> which he eventually brought to the [[Supreme Court of the Czech Republic|Czech Supreme Court]].<ref name="CPA-obit" /> Polák was also instrumental in the cases of the 1994 murder of Zdeněk Čepela in [[Tanvald]]; the 1998 murder of Milan Lacek in [[Orlová]]; a 1998 racist skinhead campaign in [[České Budějovice]]; the 2001 murder of Ota Absolon in [[Svitavy]]; and a 2010 attack by neo-Nazis in [[Benešov]].<ref name="CPA-obit" /> He also served as an editor of various Romani publications, including the ''Romano gendalos'' (transl. "Romani Mirror") between 1993 and 1995, and with a news server [[Romea.cz]] until the end of his life.<ref name="CPA-obit" /> Polák was himself attacked in August, 1999, in a restaurant in [[Karviná|Karvina]], where he was meeting government minister [[Jana Chalupova]] regarding a 1998 skinhead murder of a Romani.<ref>U.S. Dept. of State, [http://www.asylumlaw.org/docs/showDocument.cfm?documentID=31 "1999 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Czech Republic"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613144120/http://asylumlaw.org/docs/showDocument.cfm?documentID=31 |date=2010-06-13 }} (Feb. 25, 2000).</ref>
Polák was active in housing and [[squatting|squatter]]s rights movements throughout his life.<ref name="CPA-obit" /> In 1990, he co-founded a squat on Pplk. Sochora street in [[Prague]].<ref name="CPA-obit" /> He remained active in squatters' rights movements throughout the rest of his life. Even in the last months of his life, while ill with cancer, Polák worked with [[Romani people|Roma]] people in a case<ref name="CNA-obit" /> involving their eviction and relocation from their home in [[Přednádraží]], a neighborhood (sometimes described as a [[ghetto]] or [[shanty town|shantytown]]) in [[Přívoz|Ostrava-Privoz]].<ref name="romaevict">Czech News Agency, [http://praguemonitor.com/2012/08/06/roma-refuse-leave-their-ostrava-homes "Roma refuse to leave their Ostrava homes"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130201162636/http://praguemonitor.com/2012/08/06/roma-refuse-leave-their-ostrava-homes |date=2013-02-01 }}, Aug. 6, 2012.</ref>
Jakub Polák died on Tuesday 25 September 2012, from cancer.<ref name="CPA-obit" />
==Awards== * 2000 – František Kriegel Award from the [[Charter 77]] Foundation (Nadace Charty 77), for anti-racist work
==Notes== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Polak, Jakob}} [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:Czech anarchists]] [[Category:Anti-racism activists]] [[Category:Housing rights activists]] [[Category:Romani rights activists]] [[Category:Squatters]] [[Category:People of the Velvet Revolution]] [[Category:Prague Spring]]

{{BLP sources|date=April 2011}} {{more footnotes|date=September 2011}} '''Jane Grossman Stern''' and '''Michael Stern''' (both born 1946) are American writers who specialize in books about travel, food, and popular culture. They are best known for their ''[[Roadfood]]'' books, website, and magazine columns, in which they find [[road food]] restaurants serving classic American regional specialties and review them. Starting their hunt for regional American food in the early 1970s they were the first food writers to regard this food as being as worthy to report on as the [[haute cuisine]] of other nations.
Since the Sterns began documenting regional American food in the 1970s many other writers and television personalities have used their pioneering work as inspiration. In addition to their early work with regional American food the Sterns' book ''Square Meals'' (Knopf 1985) put "[[comfort food]]s" like mac and cheese, meatloaf, and mashed potatoes on the culinary map. ''Square Meals'' did an audacious reverse spin on the tricked up and precious nouvelle cuisine that was beloved by food critics at that time.
Jane Grossman grew up in [[New York City]], where she attended the [[Walden School (New York City)|Walden School]] and received a BFA in graphic design at [[Pratt Institute]] in Brooklyn. Michael Stern grew up in [[Winnetka, Illinois]], and graduated from the [[University of Michigan]] in 1968. They met as graduate students in art at [[Yale University]] and their first date, at [[Frank Pepe Pizzeria Napoletana|Pepe's Pizza]] in New Haven, had a food focus.<ref name=Ephron>{{cite news |author= [[Nora Ephron]] |title=To Taste Everything |date=May 28, 2006 |work=[[New York Times]] |url=http://events.nytimes.com/2006/05/28/books/review/28ephron.html |accessdate=2008-08-05 }}</ref> The couple married in 1970. The following year, Jane earned an MFA in painting from Yale and Michael changed schools and earned an MFA from [[Columbia University]] in film. Neither found work in their fields of study.
After a short stint of producing documentaries for WNBC, a teaching job at [[Hunter College]] and another at [[Wesleyan University]] they began work on the book that eventually became the first ''Roadfood''. The book was conceived as a book on "truck-stop dining," funded with an advance from a publisher. The Sterns set out in their car to travel through the United States and eat up to 12 meals daily at diners and local cafes.<ref name=Ephron/> The resulting first edition of ''Roadfood'' was published in 1977; the most recent edition was released in 2017.
In addition to their food writing, the Sterns have written books on American popular culture, including [[New York Times bestseller list|''The New York Times'' bestselling]] ''Elvis World'' (1987) and ''The Encyclopaedia of Bad Taste'' (1990). In all, they have written over 30 books. They were staff writers for ''[[Gourmet (magazine)|Gourmet]]'' magazine for 18 years, have written for ''[[The New Yorker]]'', ''[[The Atlantic Monthly]]'', and are now contributing editors at ''[[Saveur]]''.
They are regular guests on [[American Public Media]]'s public radio program, ''[[The Splendid Table]]''. They have won numerous awards, including [[James Beard award]]s, and were inducted into [[James Beard Foundation Award#Who's Who of Food and Beverage in America|Who's Who of Food and Beverage in America]] in 1992.<ref>[http://www.jamesbeard.org/index.php?q=james_beard_awards_whos_who Who’s Who of Food & Beverage in America], the James Beard Foundation website, accessed September 16, 2011</ref> The Sterns founded Roadfood.com; the site was sold to Fexy Media in 2016.<ref>{{Cite news| issn = 0362-4331| last = Gordinier| first = Jeff| title = Serious Eats and Roadfood Are Sold to Fexy Media| work = The New York Times| accessdate = 2017-11-13| date = 2015-06-02| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/02/dining/serious-eats-roadfood-websites-sold-to-fexy-media.html}}</ref> After the sale, the Sterns remained in charge of editorial content of their website.<ref name="eater-2015jun02">{{cite news |url=https://www.eater.com/2015/6/2/8704397/serious-eats-roadfood-seattle-fexy-media |title=Serious Eats Is Acquired by Seattle-Based Fexy Media: Roadfood has also been sold to Fexy Media. |website=Eater |date=June 2, 2015 |first=Daniela |last=Galarza}}</ref>
In 2003, Jane Stern published ''Ambulance Girl: How I Saved Myself by Becoming an EMT'', a memoir in which she described suffering from severe [[clinical depression]] when she was in her early 50s and overcame her depression by training and working as an [[emergency medical technician]] in Connecticut. In 2005 the book was made into a [[television movie]], ''[[Ambulance Girl]]'', for which actress [[Kathy Bates]] was nominated for an [[Emmy Award]]. The Sterns wrote a joint memoir, ''Two for the Road: Our Love Affair With American Food'', in 2006.
The couple divorced in 2008; they still write as a team.<ref>Nanci G. Hutson, [http://www.newstimes.com/news/article/Local-Roadfood-authors-divorce-does-not-end-221902.php Local 'Roadfood' authors' divorce does not end eating partnership], ''News-Times'' (Danbury, CT), Friday, July 3, 2009</ref> She now lives in [[Ridgefield, Connecticut]]; he and his present wife, Linda, reside in [[Aiken, South Carolina]].
In 2011 the former couple published ''The Lexicon of Real American Food'', and Jane Stern published a book on her little known but long-standing career as a [[tarot card reader]]. <ref>Nanci G. Hutson, [http://www.newstimes.com/news/article/Local-Roadfood-authors-divorce-does-not-end-221902.php Local 'Roadfood' authors' divorce does not end eating partnership], ''News-Times'' (Danbury, CT), Friday, July 3, 2009</ref>
==Bibliography== *''Trucker: A Portrait of the Last American Cowboy'' (1975, Jane Stern only) *''[[Roadfood]]'' (1977, eighth ed. 2011) *''Amazing America'' (1978) *''Auto Ads'' (1978) *''[[Douglas Sirk]]'' (1978, Michael Stern only) *''Horror Holiday'' (1981) *''Goodfood'' (1983) *''Square Meals'' (1985) (cookbook) *''Real American Food'' (1986) *''Elvis World'' (1987) *''A Taste of America'' (1988) *''The Encyclopedia of Bad Taste'' (1990) *''Sixties People'' (1990) *''American Gourmet'' (1991) *''Jane & Michael Stern's Encyclopedia of Pop Culture'' (1992) *''Way Out West'' (1993) *''Eat Your Way Across the USA'' (1997) *''Dog Eat Dog: A Very Human Book About Dogs and Dog Shows'' (1998) *''Two Puppies'' (1998) *''Chili Nation'' (1999) *''Blue Plate Specials and Blue Ribbon Chefs: The Heart And Soul Of America's Great Roadside Restaurants'' (2001) *''The Blue Willow Inn Cookbook: Discover Why the Best Small-Town Restaurant in the South is in Social Circle, Georgia'' (2002)(cookbook) *''The Harry Caray's Restaurant Cookbook: The Official Home Plate of the Chicago Cubs'' (2003) (cookbook) *''Ambulance Girl: How I Saved Myself by Becoming an EMT'' (2003, Jane Stern only) {{ISBN|978-1-4000-4832-8}} *''Elegant Comfort Food from Dorset Inn: Traditional Cooking from Vermont's Oldest Continuously Operating Inn'' (2005, with Sissy Hicks) (cookbook) *''Two for the Road: Our Love Affair With American Food'' (2006) *''Roadfood Sandwiches: Recipes and Lore from Our Favorite Shops Coast to Coast'' (2007) (cookbook) *''500 Things to Eat Before It's Too Late: and the Very Best Places to Eat Them'' (2009) *''The Lexicon of Real American Food'' (2011) *''Confessions of a Tarot Reader: Practical Advice From This Realm and Beyond'' (2011, Jane Stern only)
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.roadfood.com Official site: Roadfood.com] *[http://www.epicurious.com/restaurants/best_eats/ Epicurious.com profile]

revision.text:
{{Infobox football biography | name = Jimmy Calderwood | image = | caption = | fullname = James Calderwood | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1955|2|28|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Glasgow]], Scotland | currentclub = | position = [[Midfielder]] | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = Glasgow Amateurs | youthyears2 = 1971–1972 | youthclubs2 = [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] | years1 = 1972–1980 | years2 = 1979 | years3 = 1979–1980 | years4 = 1980–1982 | years5 = 1982–1987 | years6 = 1987–1989 | clubs1 = [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] | clubs2 = → [[Cambridge United F.C.|Cambridge United]] (loan) | clubs3 = [[Sparta Rotterdam]] | clubs4 = [[Willem II Tilburg]] | clubs5 = [[Roda JC]] | clubs6 = [[Heracles Almelo]] | caps1 = 145 | goals1 = 4 | caps2 = 8 | goals2 = 0 | caps3 = 10 | goals3 = 0 | caps4 = 44 | goals4 = 1 | caps5 = 124 | goals5 = 1 | caps6 = 33 | goals6 = 7 | totalcaps = | totalgoals= | nationalyears1 = 1974 | nationalteam1 = [[Scotland national under-23 football team|Scotland U23]] | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | manageryears1 = 1996–1997 | manageryears2 = 1997–1999 | manageryears3 = 1999–2004 | manageryears4 = 2004–2009 | manageryears5 = 2010 | manageryears6 = 2011 | manageryears7 = 2012 | manageryears8 = 2014 | managerclubs1 = [[Willem II Tilburg]] | managerclubs2 = [[NEC Nijmegen]] | managerclubs3 = [[Dunfermline Athletic F.C.|Dunfermline Athletic]] | managerclubs4 = [[Aberdeen F.C.|Aberdeen]] | managerclubs5 = [[Kilmarnock F.C.|Kilmarnock]] | managerclubs6 = [[Ross County F.C.|Ross County]] | managerclubs7 = [[Go Ahead Eagles]] | managerclubs8 = [[De Graafschap]] }} '''James Calderwood''' (born 28 February 1955) is a Scottish former [[association football|football]] player and [[manager (association football)|manager]]. Calderwood played for [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] and [[Netherlands|Dutch]] clubs [[Sparta Rotterdam]], [[Willem II Tilburg]], [[Roda JC]] and [[Heracles Almelo]]. After retiring as a player, Calderwood stayed in the Netherlands and became a coach, becoming a manager of [[Willem II Tilburg]] and [[NEC Nijmegen]].
He returned to his native Scotland in 1999 to become manager of [[Dunfermline Athletic F.C.|Dunfermline Athletic]], guiding them to the [[2004 Scottish Cup Final]]. Calderwood left Dunfermline that summer to become manager of [[Aberdeen F.C.|Aberdeen]], a position he held for five seasons. Aberdeen performed relatively well in the [[Scottish Premier League|SPL]] under Calderwood and reached the last 32 of the [[2007–08 UEFA Cup]], but suffered a number of domestic cup defeats by lower league opponents. He then had brief stints with [[Kilmarnock F.C.|Kilmarnock]] and [[Ross County F.C.|Ross County]], helping each club retain their league status. Calderwood returned to the Netherlands in March 2012, with [[Go Ahead Eagles]].
In January 2014, Calderwood spent just under a month as manager of [[De Graafschap]] before resigning. Calderwood cited the sale of several of De Graafschap's key players without adequate replacement as the reason for his resignation from the post. In July 2016, Calderwood was appointed to the board of directors at [[Cowdenbeath F.C.|Cowdenbeath]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://spfl.co.uk/news/article/calderwood-joins-cowdenbeath-board/ |title=Calderwood joins Cowdenbeath board |work= |publisher=Scottish Professional Football League |date=15 July 2016 |accessdate=17 July 2016}}</ref>
In August 2017, Calderwood revealed that he has been battling earlier-onset dementia for the past two years and is being treated for the condition.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/40949594 |title=Jimmy Calderwood: Former Aberdeen & Dunfermline boss has Alzheimer's |work= |publisher=BBC Sport Scotland |date=16 August 2017 |accessdate=16 August 2017}}</ref>
==Playing career== {{Expand section|date=May 2009}} Born in [[Govan]], [[Glasgow]], Calderwood was raised in the [[Castlemilk]] housing scheme in the city where he attended Grange Secondary School; he played in youth teams with [[Ricky Sbragia]] who also became a footballer and later a manager,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.scotsman.com/sport/sunderland_warming_to_humble_scot_sbragia_1_1152968|title=Sunderland warming to humble Scot Sbragia|newspaper=The Scotsman|date=22 December 2008|accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref><ref name=rsjc10>{{cite news|url=https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/ricky-sbragia-would-be-a-great-choice-1079180|title=Ricky Sbragia would be a great choice as the new Motherwell boss, says pal Jimmy Calderwood|newspaper=Daily Record|date=26 December 2010|accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref> and also played at schoolboy level with future Scotland captain [[Willie Miller]].<ref name="don">{{cite book|last=Miller|first=Willie|title=Willie Miller - The Don|year=2013|publisher=[[Birlinn (publisher)|Birlinn]]|isbn=9780857905505}}</ref>
He started his professional career with [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] as an apprentice in 1971, making his first team debut against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] in 1972 <ref name = "scotsman">[http://sport.scotsman.com/sport/Jimmy-Calderwood-confirmed-as-Kilmarnock.5984473.jp Jimmy Calderwood confirmed as Kilmarnock manager], ''[[The Scotsman]]'', 14 January 2010.</ref> (Sbragia joined him a year later).<ref name=rsjc10/> He made 159 appearances for the club before spending a short time on loan at [[Cambridge United F.C.|Cambridge United]] in 1979. His contract with Birmingham was cancelled at the end of the [[1979–80 in English football|1979–80 season]],<ref>{{cite book |author=Matthews, Tony |title=Birmingham City: A Complete Record |year=1995 |publisher=Breedon Books |location=Derby |isbn=978-1-85983-010-9 |page=77}}</ref> and he accepted an offer to move to the [[Netherlands]], where he spent almost 10 years playing for [[Sparta Rotterdam]], [[Willem II Tilburg]], [[Roda JC]] and [[Heracles Almelo]] before retiring in 1989.<ref name = "scotsman"/>
==Managerial career==
=== Netherlands === Calderwood first became a coach in 1991, of amateur club [[Rietvogels of Almelo]].<ref name = "scotsman"/> A year later he became an assistant coach of professional club [[FC Zwolle]],<ref name = "scotsman"/> before moving in 1993 to [[Cambuur Leeuwarden]].<ref name = "scotsman"/> He returned to [[Willem II Tilburg]] in 1995, initially as assistant coach before becoming the manager of the club a year later.<ref name = "scotsman"/> A year later, he moving to the managerial position at [[NEC Nijmegen]].<ref name = "scotsman"/>
=== Dunfermline === {{Expand section|date=May 2009}} After a two-year spell with NEC, [[Scottish Football League First Division|Scottish First Division]] side [[Dunfermline Athletic F.C.|Dunfermline Athletic]] moved to make him their new manager. Calderwood spent five seasons at [[East End Park]], where he led the club to promotion to the SPL in his [[1999–2000 Scottish First Division|first season]] in charge.<ref name = "scotsman"/> He also led them to their highest ever SPL position, finishing fourth in [[2003–04 in Scottish football|2003–04]]. That season the side also reached the [[2004 Scottish Cup Final]],<ref name = "scotsman"/> guaranteeing their return to European competition<ref name = "scotsman"/> for the first time in 35 years as opponents [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] had already earned [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] qualification.
=== Aberdeen === In the summer of 2004 [[Willie Miller]], returning to [[Pittodrie Stadium|Pittodrie]] as director of football, brought Calderwood to [[Aberdeen F.C.|Aberdeen]] to replace [[Steve Paterson]] as manager.<ref name="Move to Aberdeen">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/a/aberdeen/3745299.stm|publisher=BBC Sport website|title=Calderwood agrees Dons move|date=28 May 2004}}</ref> Calderwood oversaw an improvement in Aberdeen's fortunes on the playing field. They narrowly missed out on qualifying for European competition in [[2004–05 in Scottish football|2004–05]] and [[2005–06 in Scottish football|2005–06]] but finished the [[2006–07 in Scottish football|2006–07]] league campaign in third place, ensuring [[UEFA Cup]] qualification. However, there was humiliation for his team when they were eliminated from the [[2006–07 Scottish League Cup]] by the amateur club [[Queen's Park F.C.|Queen's Park]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_cups/5271286.stm|title=Queen's Pk 0-0 Aberdeen (5-3 pen) |work=BBC Sport |date=22 August 2006 |accessdate=24 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afcheritage.org/matches/fixtures/mreport.cfm?fixture_id=4809&Season=2006-07|title=Dons spot of bother ends in humiliation |work=AFC Heritage trust|date=22 August 2006 |accessdate=24 October 2017}}</ref>
In December 2007, Calderwood led Aberdeen to the last 32 of European competition for the first time since 1986 with a surprising 4–0 demolition of [[FC Copenhagen]] at Pittodrie. With this great achievement, the Dons were rewarded by drawing [[FC Bayern Munich]]. Calderwood's team drew 2–2 with Bayern at Pittodrie on 14 February 2008, but the Germans pulled off a convincing 5–1 win the following week. Calderwood signed a {{frac|3|1|2}}-year contract to end a month of speculation about his future, along with assistant manager [[Jimmy Nicholl]] and coach [[Sandy Clark]].
Calderwood took Aberdeen to the [[2007–08 Scottish Cup]] semi final, where they lost 4–3 to [[Dumfries]] First Division side, [[Queen of the South F.C.|Queen of the South]]. This was despite two goals and an assist from [[Barry Nicholson]] playing against his hometown club.
The [[2008–09 in Scottish football|2008–09 season]] saw Calderwood come in for some stern criticism following the club's poor start to the campaign. The Dons failed to win any of their opening four home matches, and were beaten 4–2 by Kilmarnock in the League Cup. Fans became impatient with some claiming it was time for a fresh start just as the team recovered form and were in the race for third place.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sundayherald.com/sport/shfootball/display.var.2453843.0.0.php?act=complaint&cid=1922682 |title=See you, Jimmy... |newspaper=Sunday Herald |date=27 September 2008 |accessdate=5 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120806135511/http://www.heraldscotland.com/see-you-jimmy-1.833460 |archivedate=6 August 2012}}</ref> On 18 January 2009 Calderwood led Aberdeen to a memorable 4–2 victory over Celtic that propelled Aberdeen to third in the league. However, just three league wins followed in the next 16 and Calderwood left the club "by mutual consent" on 24 May 2009, after the team had qualified for a place in the [[UEFA Europa League]] with a 2–1 victory over Hibernian.<ref name="Dons part with manager Calderwood">{{cite news| title = Dons part with manager Calderwood| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/a/aberdeen/8066189.stm| publisher = BBC Sport| date = 2009-05-24| accessdate = 2009-05-24}}</ref>
===Kilmarnock=== Calderwood was appointed manager of [[Kilmarnock F.C.|Kilmarnock]] on 14 January 2010, succeeding [[Jim Jefferies (footballer)|Jim Jefferies]].<ref name = "scotsman"/> He agreed to a contract with the club until the end of the 2009–10 season.<ref name = "scotsman"/> Calderwood managed to secure Kilmarnock's SPL status for another season, but left the club in the summer after disagreeing with chairman Michael Johnston about the player and coaching budgets.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://sport.scotsman.com/sport/Kilmarnock-part-company-with-Jimmy.6330324.jp |title=Kilmarnock part company with Jimmy Calderwood |work=scotsman.com |date=31 May 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref>
===Ross County=== On 16 February 2011, Calderwood agreed to fill the managerial post at [[Scottish Football League First Division|First Division]] club [[Ross County F.C.|Ross County]] until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/r/ross_county/9396586.stm |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |author=[[Jim Spence (broadcaster)|Spence, Jim]] |accessdate=16 February 2011 |date=16 February 2011 |title=Jimmy Calderwood takes Ross County post}}</ref>
===Go Ahead Eagles=== Calderwood was appointed coach of [[Go Ahead Eagles]] in the [[Eerste Divisie]] on 30 March 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jimmy Calderwood: Marc Overmars was key in my decision to join Go Ahead Eagles|url=http://sport.stv.tv/football/scottish-premier/aberdeen/302084-jimmy-calderwood-marc-overmars-was-key-in-my-decision-to-join-go-ahead-eagles/|publisher=STV|accessdate=31 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/football/world-football/2012/03/31/jimmy-calderwood-back-in-management-as-interim-boss-for-dutch-hopefuls-go-ahead-eagles-86908-23808116/|title=Jimmy Calderwood back in management as interim boss for Dutch hopefuls Go Ahead Eagles |work=Daily Record|publisher=Trinity Mirror|date=31 March 2012|accessdate=1 April 2012|first=|last=}}</ref> He left the [[Deventer]] club after they were knocked out of the promotion play-offs by [[FC Den Bosch]] after the second leg of their double-header on May 13.<ref>http://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/scotsol/homepage/sport/article4345552.ece</ref> In two separate interviews with John Hunt for [[The Scottish Sun]], Calderwood acknowledged that he knew his tenure at Go Ahead Eagles was only until the end of the season/play-offs.<ref>http://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/scotsol/homepage/sport/4345552/Caldo-wants-to-be-boss-again.html</ref>
===De Graafschap=== Calderwood was appointed manager of [[De Graafschap]] in January 2014.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/jimmy-calderwood-returns-football-takes-3031176 |title=Jimmy Calderwood returns to football as he takes the reins at Dutch side De Graafschap |first=Ian |last=Orr |work=Daily Record |publisher=Trinity Mirror |date=17 January 2014 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref> He left the club after less than a month in the job, furious at the sale of two key players before the start of the season. His decision to quit was not well received by the players, with club captain [[Edwin Linssen]] saying: "When we were told, we were very depressed. It’s not good, it’s a sad day for the club." <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/european-round-up-jimmy-calderwoods-sudden-3154314|title=European round-up: Jimmy Calderwood's sudden departure sparks mutiny at Dutch club De Graafschap|first=|last=Dailyrecord.co.uk|date=17 February 2014|publisher=}}</ref>
==Honours== ;Dunfermline Athletic *[[Fife Cup]] (2): 2000–01, 2002–03 *[[Scottish Football League First Division|Scottish First Division]] promotion (1): [[1999–2000 Scottish First Division|1999–00]]
;Ross County *[[Scottish Challenge Cup]] (1): [[2010 Scottish Challenge Cup Final|2010–11]]

'''Johanan ben Aaron ben Nathanael Luria''' ({{lang-he|יוחנן בן אהרן בן נתנאל לוריא}}) was an [[Alsatians (people)|Alsatian]] [[Talmudist]]. He lived successively at [[Niedernheim]] and [[Strasbourg|Strasburg]] at the end of the fifteenth century and in the beginning of the sixteenth. After having studied for many years in German ''[[yeshivot]]'', he returned to [[Alsace]] and settled in Strasburg, where he founded a ''[[yeshiva]]'' by permission of the government. Luria was the author of an [[ethical]] work entitled "''Hadrakah''" ([[Cracow]], c. 1579) and of "''Meshibat Nefesh''" ([[Adolf Neubauer|Neubauer]], "''Catalogue of the Hebrew MSS. in the Bodleian Library''" No. 257), an ''[[aggadic]]'' and [[Jewish mysticism|mystical]] [[Jewish commentaries on the Bible|commentary]] on the [[Pentateuch]], founded on [[Rashi]]. To this commentary was appended a [[dissertation]] in which Luria refuted the arguments advanced by Christians against Judaism.{{Jewish Encyclopedia|inline=1|title=Johanan ben Aaron ben Nathanael Luria|url=http://jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/10192-luria#anchor11|accessdate=Jan 18, 2015}}
'''Jewish Encyclopedia Bibliography:''' *[[Eliakim Carmoly|Carmoly]], ''Itinéraires de la Terre Sainte'', [https://archive.org/stream/itinrairesdelate00carm#page/345/mode/1up p. 345]; *[[Leopold Zunz|Zunz]], ''{{abbr|Z. G.|Zur Geschichte und Literatur}}'' pp. 106-130; [https://books.google.com/books?id=514pAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&hl=iw#v=onepage&q&f=false] *''{{abbr|Orient, Lit.|Literaturblatt des Orients}}'' xi. 546; *[[Moritz Steinschneider|Steinschneider]], ''{{abbr|Cat. Bodl.|Catalogue of the Hebrew Books in the Bodleian Library}}'' col. 1398. One of his descendants was [[Elijah Loans]].{{Cite Jewish Encyclopedia|url=http://jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/10049-loans-elijah-ben-moses-ashkenazi|title=LOANS, ELIJAH BEN MOSES ASHKENAZI or LOANZ|accessdate=Jan 21, 2015}} == References == {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Luria, Johanan}} [[Category:15th-century rabbis]] [[Category:16th-century rabbis]] [[Category:Alsatian Jews]] [[Category:Bible commentators]] [[Category:Kabbalists]] [[Category:People from Strasbourg]] [[Category:Place of birth missing]] [[Category:Place of death missing]] [[Category:Rosh yeshivas]] [[Category:Year of birth missing]] [[Category:Year of death missing]] [[Category:Talmudists]] {{france-rabbi-stub}}

{{BLP sources|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox person | image = | caption = | name = Larenz Tate | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1975|9|8}}{{cite web |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0yh2AAAAMAAJ&q=larenz+tate+1975&dq=larenz+tate+1975&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiphsfg4OHWAhXHSiYKHYGdBk0Q6AEILDAB |title=Contemporary Black Biography: Profiles from the International Black Community, Volume 15 |last=Phelps|first=Shirelle|date=1997 |website=Google Books |publisher=Gale |access-date=October 8, 2017 |quote=}}{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wxa7BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA456&dq=larenz+tate+1975&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiphsfg4OHWAhXHSiYKHYGdBk0Q6AEIOjAE#v=onepage&q=larenz+tate+1975&f=false|title=Historical Dictionary of African American Television|first1=Kathleen|last1=Fearn-Banks|first2=Anne|last2=Burford-Johnson|date=3 October 2014|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|accessdate=4 October 2018|via=Google Books}}{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q0G3hog_c2kC&pg=PA33&dq=larenz+tate+1975&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiphsfg4OHWAhXHSiYKHYGdBk0Q6AEINTAD#v=onepage&q=larenz+tate+1975&f=false|title=Screen World 2001|first1=John|last1=Willis|first2=Barry|last2=Monush|date=25 March 2002|publisher=Hal Leonard Corporation|accessdate=4 October 2018|via=Google Books}} | birth_place = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], U.S. | nationality = [[Americans|American]] | education = [[Palmdale High School]] | occupation = Actor | years_active = 1985–present | known_for = Peter Waters – ''[[Crash (2004 film)|Crash]]''
O-Dog – ''[[Menace II Society]]'' | spouse = | children = }} '''Larenz Tate''' (born September 8, 1975{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UCCkhsztnYgC&pg=PA375&dq=larenz+tate+1975&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiphsfg4OHWAhXHSiYKHYGdBk0Q6AEIMDAC#v=onepage&q=larenz+tate+1975&f=false|title=Screen World: 2005 Film Annual|first1=John|last1=Willis|first2=Barry|last2=Monush|date=1 April 2006|publisher=Hal Leonard Corporation|accessdate=4 October 2018|via=Google Books}}{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W28vCHtlJyUC&pg=PA321&dq=larenz+tate+1975&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiphsfg4OHWAhXHSiYKHYGdBk0Q6AEIVTAJ#v=onepage&q=larenz+tate+1975&f=false|title=The A to Z of African American Cinema|first1=S. Torriano|last1=Berry|first2=Venise T.|last2=Berry|date=2 September 2009|publisher=Scarecrow Press|accessdate=4 October 2018|via=Google Books}}) is an [[Americans|American]] [[film]] and [[television]] [[actor]]. Tate is best known for his roles as Peter Waters in ''[[Crash (2004 film)|Crash]]'' and as O-Dog in the 1993 [[teen film|teen]] [[hood film|hood drama film]], ''[[Menace II Society]]''. Tate's other films include ''[[Dead Presidents]]'', ''[[Love Jones (film)|Love Jones]]'', ''[[Why Do Fools Fall in Love (film)|Why Do Fools Fall in Love]]'', ''[[A Man Apart]]'', ''[[Waist Deep]]'', ''[[Biker Boyz]]'', and ''[[Ray (film)|Ray]]''. ==Early life== Larenz Tate was born on Chicago, Illinois' [[West Side, Chicago|west side]], in a middle-class suburb, to Peggy and Larry Tate.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/36/Larenz-Tate.html|title=Larenz Tate profile|website=Filmreference.com|date=1975-09-08|accessdate=2010-10-06}} Tate is the youngest of three siblings (his two brothers, Larron and Lahmard, are also actors) whose family moved to [[California]] when he was 4 years old. Convinced by their parents to enter a drama program at the Inner City Cultural Center, the trio did not take the lessons seriously until classmate [[Malcolm-Jamal Warner]]'s ascent to fame after being cast on the sitcom ''[[The Cosby Show]]''. Subsequently, realizing that they could parlay their efforts into a tangible form of success, the siblings began to receive small roles and in 1985, Tate made his small-screen debut in an episode of ''[[The Twilight Zone (1985 TV series)|The New Twilight Zone]]''.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} Tate attended [[Palmdale High School]], graduating in 1993.{{cite web|url=http://www.phsfalcons.org/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=289292&type=d&pREC_ID=698628|title=Hall of Fame - Alumni - Palmdale High School|website=Phsfalcons.org|accessdate=4 October 2018}} ==Career== Following appearances in such television series as ''[[21 Jump Street]]'' and ''[[The Wonder Years]]'', Tate was cast in the television movie ''[[The Women of Brewster Place (miniseries)|The Women of Brewster Place]]'' before receiving the recurring role of Steve Urkel's nemesis, Willie Fuffner, in the family comedy series ''[[Family Matters]]'' (1989). He was also a cast member on the [[CBS]] series ''[[The Royal Family (TV series)|The Royal Family]]'', starring [[Redd Foxx]] and [[Della Reese]], which ended prematurely after Redd Foxx died. In the video game ''[[187 Ride or Die]]'', Tate voices the main character, Buck. Following numerous small-screen roles, offers began pouring in for Tate, and in late 1992, collaborative filmmaking siblings [[Hughes brothers|Albert and Allen Hughes]] approached him to star in their debut feature ''[[Menace II Society]]''.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} The film found Tate channeling his substantial energy into creating "O-Dog", a trigger-happy teenager. Following up with the little-seen but often-praised television series ''[[South Central (TV series)|South Central]]'', Tate would later appear in the family comedy-drama ''[[The Inkwell]]'' (1994) before re-teaming with the Hughes brothers for ''[[Dead Presidents]]'' (1995) and taking on the role of a love-stricken young poet in the romantic drama ''[[Love Jones (film)|Love Jones]]'' (1997). Larenz Tate also played the role of Kenny in ''[[The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air]]'' in the episode "That's No Lady, That's My Cousin".{{cite web| url= https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0583036/reference| title= ''The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air'' (TV series): That's No Lady, That's My Cousin| website=IMDb.com| access-date= April 16, 2018}} There followed roles in ''[[The Postman (film)|The Postman]]'' (as the automotively monikered Ford Lincoln Mercury), the [[Frankie Lymon]] biopic ''[[Why Do Fools Fall in Love (film)|Why Do Fools Fall in Love]]'' (1998, with Tate as Lymon), and 2000's ''Love Come Down''. Though a big theatrical release had eluded Tate for the first few years of the millennial turnover, Tate would soon turn up opposite [[Laurence Fishburne]] in the high-octane but critically derided ''[[Biker Boyz]]'' (2003){{cite web|url=http://uk.rottentomatoes.com/m/biker_boyz/ |title= Biker Boyz |website=Rottentomatoes.com |date= |accessdate=2010-10-06}} ''[[A Man Apart]]'' (2003), ''[[Crash (2004 film)|Crash]]'' (2004), as music legend [[Quincy Jones]] in ''[[Ray (film)|Ray]]'' (2004), and ''[[Waist Deep]]'' (2006). Larenz was also featured in [[rhythm and blues|R&B]] singer [[Ashanti (singer)|Ashanti]]'s 2003 released music video ''[[Rain on Me]]'', where he played the jealous, abusive spouse of Ashanti. The video touched on the subject of domestic abuse. He also starred as part of the main cast in season's 4-7 of [[FX (TV channel)|FX]]'s ''[[Rescue Me (U.S. TV series)|Rescue Me]]'' as Bart "Black Shawn" Johnston.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} ==Select filmography== * ''[[The Twilight Zone (1985 TV series)|The Twilight Zone]]'' (1985) (one episode, "[[Night of the Meek]]"): Older Brother * ''[[Hunter (1984 U.S. TV series)|Hunter]]'' (1987) (One episode, "Crossfire"): Sporty's Nephew * ''[[Amen (TV series)|Amen]]'' (1988) (One episode, "Get Em Up, Scout"): Leshawn * ''[[21 Jump Street]]'' (1989) (One episode, "Wolly Bullies"): Young Adam Fuller * ''[[The Wonder Years]]'' (1989) (Season 2 Episode 9, "Loosiers"): Basketball Team Captain * ''[[The Women of Brewster Place (miniseries)|The Women of Brewster place]]'' (1989) (TV): Sammy * ''[[Matlock (TV series)|Matlock]]'' (1989) (One episode, "The Scrooge"): Street Kid #3 * ''[[New Attitude (TV series)|New Attitude]]'' (1990) (TV): Chilly D * ''[[Family Matters]]'' (1990–1991) (2 episodes, "Life of the Party" and "Requiem for an Urkel"): Willie Fuffner * ''[[The Royal Family (TV series)|The Royal Family]]'' (1991-1992) (15 episodes): Curtis Royal * ''[[The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air]]'' (1992) (1 episode, "That's No Lady, That's My Cousin"): Kenny * ''[[Menace II Society]]'' (1993): Kevin "O-Dog" Anderson * ''[[South Central (TV series)|South Central]]'' (1994) (TV): Andre Mosely * ''[[The Inkwell]]'' (1994): Drew Tate * ''[[Dead Presidents]]'' (1995): Anthony Curtis * ''[[Love Jones (film)|Love Jones]]'' (1997): Darius Lovehall * ''[[The Postman (film)|The Postman]]'' (1997): Ford Lincoln Mercury * ''[[Why Do Fools Fall in Love (film)|Why Do Fools Fall in Love]]'' (1998): [[Frankie Lymon]] * ''[[Love Come Down (film)|Love Come Down]]'' (2000): Neville Carter * ''[[Biker Boyz]]'' (2003): Wood * ''[[A Man Apart]]'' (2003): Demetrius Hicks * ''[[Crash (2004 film)|Crash]]'' (2004): Peter Waters * ''[[Ray (film)|Ray]]'' (2004): [[Quincy Jones]] * ''[[187 Ride or Die]]'' (2005) (Video Game): Buck (Voice) * ''[[Waterfront (TV series)|Waterfront]]'' (2006) (6 episodes): Marcus * ''[[Waist Deep]]'' (2006): Lucky * ''[[Love Monkey]]'' (2006) (8 episodes): Shooter Cooper * ''[[Rescue Me (U.S. TV series)|Rescue Me]]'' (2007–2011) (TV): Bart "Black Shawn" Johnston * ''Gun Hill'' (2011): Bird Stevens and twin brother * ''[[Justified (TV series)|Justified]]'' (1 episode; For Blood or Money): Clinton (uncredited) * ''[[House of Lies (TV series)|House of Lies]]'' (2013–2015) (TV): Malcolm Kaan * ''[[Unity (film)|Unity]]'' (2014): Narrator * ''[[Rush (U.S. TV series)|Rush]]'' (2014): [http://www.usanetwork.com/rush/cast/dr-alex-burke Dr. Alex Burke] * ''White Water'' (2015): Terrance * ''[[Beta Test (film)|Beta Test]]'' (2015): Max * ''[[Hell's Kitchen (U.S. TV series)|Hell's Kitchen]]'' (2016): Himself * ''[[Game of Silence (U.S. TV series)|Game of Silence]]'' (2016): Shawn Cook * ''[[Girls Trip]]'' (2017): Julian * ''[[Deuces (film)|Deuces]]'' (2017): Deuces * ''[[Power (TV series)|Power]]'' (2017–Present): Councilman Tate ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.fastlifeshow.com/2012/12/with-revered-menacing-actor-authenticity-actor-larenz-tate-prepares-to-take-it-to-the-house-of-lies Larenz Tate on ''Menace II Society'' and ''House of Lies''], fastlifeshow.com, December 2012; accessed September 18, 2015. *{{IMDb name|0005478}} {{Satellite Award for Best Cast – Television Series}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tate, Larenz}} [[Image:Lazarus and Joannes Baptista Colloredo.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Lazarus and his brother Joannes Baptista in a contemporary etching.]]
'''Lazarus Colloredo''' and '''Joannes Baptista Colloredo''' (1617 – after 1646) were [[Italy|Italian]] [[conjoined twins]] who toured in 17th-century Europe. They were born in [[Genoa]], [[Italy]].
The upper body and left leg of Joannes Baptista (named after [[John the Baptist]]) stuck out of his mobile brother Lazarus. He did not speak and kept his eyes closed and mouth open all the time and was a [[parasitic twin]]. According to a later account by [[Copenhagen]] anatomist [[Thomas Bartholinus]], if someone pushed the breast of Joannes Baptista, he moved his hands, ears and lips.
To make a living, Lazarus toured around Europe and visited at least [[Basel]], [[Switzerland]] and Copenhagen, [[Denmark]] before he arrived in [[Scotland]] in 1642 and later visited the court of [[Charles I of England]].
They also visited [[Gdańsk]], [[Turkey]] and [[Denmark]], and toured [[Germany]] and Italy in 1646.<ref>Bondeson, Jan. (2000) ''The Two-Headed Boy, and Other Medical Marvels'' {{ISBN|978-0-8014-3767-0}}</ref>
Contemporary accounts described Lazarus as courteous and handsome but for his brother who just dangled before him. When Lazarus was not exhibiting himself, he covered his brother with his [[cloak]] to avoid unnecessary attention.
Later accounts claim that Lazarus married and sired several children, none with his condition. His engraved portrait depicts him in a costume of a [[courtier]] of the period of the [[House of Stuart]].
The brothers' exact date of death is unknown.
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *Gould, George M. & Pyle, and Walter L. (1896) ''[http://etext.lib.virginia.edu/toc/modeng/public/GouAnom.html Anomalies and Curiosities of Medicine].'' Retrieved July 5, 2007. *"[https://web.archive.org/web/20070708003942/http://www.phreeque.com/lazarus.html Lazarus and Johannes Baptista Colloredo]." (n.d.). ''Phreeque.com.'' Retrieved July 5, 2007.
{{authoritycontrol}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Colloredo, Lazarus and Joannes}} [[Category:1617 births]] [[Category:1640s deaths]] [[Category:Conjoined twins]] [[Category:People of the Republic of Genoa]] [[Category:Twin people from Italy]]
