{{Alsace sidebar}} {{Lorraine sidebar}} This is an incomplete '''list of well-known [[Alsace|Alsatians]] and [[Lorraine (region)|Lorrainians]]''' (people from the region of [[Alsace]] and the region of [[Lorraine (region)|Lorraine]]).
==Alsatians== *[[Jakob Ammann]] (1644–between 1712 and 1730), [[anabaptist]] [[preacher]] and namesake of [[Amish]] movement *[[Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi]] (1834–1904), sculptor, designer of the [[Statue of Liberty]] *[[Hippolyte Bernheim]] (1840–1919), neurologist *[[René Beeh]] (1886−1922), artist *[[Marc Bloch]] (1886–1944), historian *[[Jean Arp]] (1886–1966), artist *[[Hans Bethe]] (1906–2005), [[nuclear physicist]], 1967 [[Nobel Prize in Physics]] laureate *[[Mehdi Baala]] (born 1978) *[[Karl Brandt (Nazi physician)|Karl Brandt]] *[[Sébastien Brant]] *[[Martin Bucer]] *[[Wolfgang Capito]]
* [[Johann Stephan Decker]] (1784–1844), painter *[[Gustave Doré]], artist, engraver, illustrator and sculptor *[[Alfred Dreyfus]], military officer *[[Charles de Foucauld]] *[[Charles Friedel]] *[[Charles Frédéric Gerhardt]] *[[Gottfried von Strassburg]] *[[Johann Herrmann]] *[[Josel of Rosheim]] *[[Caspar Isenmann]] *[[Valérien Ismaël]] *[[Alfred Kastler]] *[[François Christophe Kellermann]] *[[Jean-Baptiste Kléber]] *[[Maurice Koechlin]] *[[Katia and Maurice Krafft]] *[[Herrad of Landsberg]] *[[Jean-Marie Lehn]] *[[Pope Leo IX]] *[[Sébastien Loeb]] *[[Philip James de Loutherbourg]] *[[Ludwig I of Bavaria]] *[[Marcel Marceau]] *[[Master of the Drapery Studies]] *[[Paul-Henri Mathieu]] *[[Yvan Muller]] *[[Charles Münch]] *[[Thomas Murner]] *[[Victor Nessler]] *[[Jean Frédéric Oberlin]] *[[Jérémie Jacques Oberlin]] *[[Thierry Omeyer]] *[[Pierre Pflimlin]] *[[Jean Rapp]] *[[Beatus Rhenanus]] *[[Claude Rich]] *[[Paul Rohmer]] *[[Andreas Franz Wilhelm Schimper]] *[[Wilhelm Philippe Schimper]] *[[Morgan Schneiderlin]] *[[Schlumberger brothers]] *[[Martin Schongauer]] *[[Albert Schweitzer]] *[[Philipp Jacob Spener]] *[[Sebastian Stoskopff]] *[[Jacques Sturm]] *[[Charles Xavier Thomas]] *[[Catherine Trautmann]] *[[Marie Tussaud]] *[[Tomi Ungerer]] *[[Emile Waldteufel]] *[[Jean-Jacques Waltz]] *[[Arsène Wenger]] *[[Jacob Wimpfeling]] *[[Charles-Adolphe Wurtz]] *[[William Wyler]]
==Lotharingians== *[[Raymond Aron]] *[[Maurice Barrès]] *[[Jacques Callot]] *[[Emile Durkheim]], sociologist *[[Emile Gallé]] *[[Claude Gellée]] *[[Joan of Arc]], national [[Hero|heroine]] of France *[[Jean Lurçat]] *[[Marcel Mauss]] *[[Michel Platini]] *[[Henri Poincaré]], mathematician and physicist *[[Raymond Poincaré]], President of France
==Undesignated== *[[Léon Blum]] (Alsatian extraction) *[[Daniel Blumenthal (politician)|Daniel Blumenthal]] *[[Ettore Bugatti|Ettore]] and [[Jean Bugatti]], automotive designers *[[Albert Carré]], opera director *[[Henri Cartan]] *[[Claude, Duke of Guise]] *[[Paul Colin (artist)|Paul Colin]] *[[Robert de Cotte]] *[[Darry Cowl]] *[[Pierre Dac]] *[[Mireille Delunsch]] *[[Emile Erckmann]] *[[Alfred Faust]] *[[Charles Fehrenbach (astronomer)]] *[[Jules Ferry]] *[[Johann Fischart]] *[[René Fonck]] *[[Francis I, Holy Roman Emperor|Franz I]], [[Holy Roman Emperor]]. *[[Pierre Fresnay]] *[[Émile Friant]] *[[Henri Grégoire]] *[[Antoine Griezmann]] *[[Johannes Gutenberg]], invented movable type printing *[[Counts of Habsburg]] *[[Jean-Jacques Henner]] *[[Hugo Hergesell]] *[[Rouget de l'Isle]] *[[Patricia Kaas]] *[[Marie Pierre Koenig]] *[[Antoine Charles Louis Lasalle]], general *[[Stanislaus I Leszczyński, King of Poland]] *[[Jules Bastien-Lepage]] *[[Charles Loeffler]] *[[Lothair II of Lotharingia]] *[[Johanan Luria]] *[[Hubert Lyautey]] *[[Nathalie Marquay]] *[[André Maurois]], author *[[Jules Méline]] *[[Michel Ney]] *[[François-Joseph Offenstein]] *[[Pilâtre de Rozier]] *[[Rabbenu Gershom]] *[[Louis Ratisbonne]] *[[Pierre-Louis Roederer]] *[[Richard Rohmer]] (Alsatian extraction) *[[Maurice de Saxe]] *[[Johannes Schefferus]] *[[Francis Schlatter]] *[[Victor Schoelcher]] *[[Robert Schuman]] *[[Paul Schutzenberger]] *[[Jean-Jacques Servan-Schreiber]] (Alsatian extraction) *[[Sébastien Le Prestre de Vauban]] *[[Paul Verlaine]], poet *[[Zwentibold]]

revision.text:
[[File:French - Coin Cabinet with Royal Arms of Louis XIV - Walters 7315.jpg|thumb|200px|Coin cabinet with the royal arms of [[Louis XIV]].]] The first [[Coin collecting|coin collector]] is said to have been [[Augustus]]. During the [[Renaissance]], it became a [[fad]] among some members of the privileged classes, especially kings and queens.<ref>{{cite web |title=Brief History of Coin Collecting |url=http://www.2-clicks-coins.com/article/coin-collecting-history.html |work=www.2-clicks-coins.com|publisher= |accessdate=26 August 2009}}</ref>
A coin collector is different from a [[numismatist]], which is someone who studies coins. Many collectors are also numismatists, but some are not. Likewise, not all numismatists collect coins themselves.
{{Dynamic list}}
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Collector !! Dates !! Notes !! Reference |- | [[Caesar Augustus]] || 63 BC – 14 AD || According to [[Suetonius]], he gave "coins of every device, including old pieces of the kings and foreign money" as [[Saturnalia]] gifts. || <ref>[[Suetonius]], ''Augustus'' [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Suetonius/12Caesars/Augustus*.html#75 75 on-line text].</ref> |- | [[Pope Boniface VIII]] || 1230 – 1303 || || <ref name=Georganteli>{{cite book|last1=Georganteli|first1=Eurydike|title=The Oxford Handbook of Byzantine Studies|chapter=Numismatics|date=2008|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|page=158|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=liFKua_cWL8C&pg=PA158|accessdate=11 May 2015|isbn=9780199252466}}</ref> |- | [[Giovanni Mansionario]] || died 1337 || Collected [[Roman currency|Roman imperial coins]] || <ref name=Karet>{{cite book|last1=Karet|first1=Evelyn|title=The Antonio II Badile Album of Drawings: The Origins of Collecting Drawings in Early Modern Northern Italy|date=2014|publisher=[[Ashgate Publishing]]|page=108|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F8EDSCj3rc8C&pg=PA108|accessdate=27 April 2015|isbn=9780754665717}}</ref> |- | [[Francesco Petrarch]] || 1304 – 1374 || Presented some of his Roman coins to [[Emperor Charles IV]] || <ref name=Karet /><ref>{{cite web|last1=Ogilvie|first1=Brian W.|title=Petrarch’s historicism and the purpose of philosophy|url=http://petrarch.petersadlon.com/submissions/Ogilvie.pdf|accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref> |- | [[Francesco I da Carrara]] || 1325 – 1393 || Collected Roman imperial coins || <ref name=Karet /> |- | [[John, Duke of Berry|Jean, duc de Berry]] || 1340 – 1416 || Commissioned copies of the medals in his collection || <ref>{{cite web|title=American Numismatic Society acquires the Guido Kisch collection of legal medals, tokens and coins|url=http://www.coinlink.com/News/clubs-associations/american-numismatic-society-acquires-the-guido-kisch-collection-of-legal-medals-tokens-and-coins/|publisher=[[American Numismatic Society]]|accessdate=2 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=M 269|url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=943351&partId=1|publisher=[[British Museum]]|accessdate=2 May 2015}}</ref> |- | [[Alfonso V of Aragon]] || 1396 – 1458 || Had a collection of ancient coins which had been discovered in Italy; carried them with him in an ivory cabinet || <ref name=Utility>{{cite journal|title=On the Utility of Medals|journal=[[The Scots Magazine]]|volume=60|pages=168–170|date=July 1798|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RT8zAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA168|accessdate=14 July 2015}}</ref> |- | [[Leonello d'Este, Marquis of Ferrara|Leonello d'Este]] || 1407 – 1450 || Collected [[Ancient Greek coinage|Greek]] and Roman coins || <ref>{{cite web|title=Cast bronze medal of Leonello d'Este, Marchese of Ferrara, by Pisanello|url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/cm/c/cast_bronze_medal_of_leonello.aspx|publisher=[[British Museum]]|accessdate=2 May 2015}}</ref> |- | [[Pope Paul II]] || 1417 – 1571 || Collected ancient coins, and had about a hundred gold and a thousand silver coins; "was able at a glance to tell where an ancient coin came from" || <ref name=Pastor>{{cite book|last=Pastor|first=Ludwig|author-link=Ludwig von Pastor|title=The History of the Popes from the Close of the Middle Ages|url=http://www.cristoraul.com/ENGLISH/History-of-the-Popes/PASTOR/VOLUME_4/2-PLATINA-AND-POMPONIUS-LAETUS.html|volume= IV|accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Lorenzo>{{cite book|last1=Fusco|first1=Laurie|last2=Corti|first2=Gino|title=Lorenzo de’ Medici: Collector and Antiquarian|date=2006|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|page=6|url=http://www.beck-shop.de/fachbuch/leseprobe/9780521452458_Excerpt_001.pdf|accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref> |- | [[Julius Pomponius Laetus]] || 1428 – 1498 || || <ref name=Pastor /> |- | [[Matthias Corvinus]] || 1443 – 1490 || || <ref name=Utility /> |- | [[Lorenzo de' Medici]] || 1449 – 1492 || Purchased coins that had been in [[Pope Paul II]]'s collection || <ref name=Lorenzo /> |- | [[Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor|Maximilian I]] || 1459 – 1519 || || <ref>[http://www.monacorarecoins.com/rare-coin-articles/coin-collectors-emperor-maximilian/ Coin Collectors: Emperor Maximilian]</ref> |- | [[Guillaume Budé]] || 1467 – 1540 || Wrote ''De Asse et Partibus Eius'' (1514) on Roman coins and [[Ancient Roman units of measurement|measures]] || <ref>{{cite book|title=The Oxford Handbook of Hellenic Studies|date=2009|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|page=1327|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n3sfjh_l61gC&pg=PT1327|accessdate=5 May 2015|isbn=9780191608704}}</ref> |- | [[Cuthbert Tunstall]] || 1474 – 1559 || || <ref name=Parr>{{cite book|last1=James|first1=Susan|title=Catherine Parr: Henry VIII's Last Love|date=2010|publisher=[[The History Press]]|page=33|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Rhk7AwAAQBAJ&pg=PA33|accessdate=22 March 2015|isbn=9780752462523}}</ref> |- | [[Ferdinand I, Holy Roman Emperor|Ferdinand I]] || 1503 – 1564 || Collected Roman coins || <ref name=Kunsthistorisches>{{cite web|title=History of the collection|url=http://www.khm.at/en/visit/collections/coin-collection/history-of-the-collection/|publisher=[[Kunsthistorisches Museum]]|accessdate=14 May 2015}}</ref> |- | [[Joachim II Hector, Elector of Brandenburg]] || 1505 – 1571 || Established the [[Berlin Coin Cabinet]] || <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Weisser|first1=Bernhard|title=The Berlin Coin Cabinet Reopens|journal=[[American Numismatic Society|ANS Magazine]]|date=2004|volume=4|issue=3|url=http://ansmagazine.com/Winter04/Berlin|accessdate=22 March 2015}}</ref> |- | [[Catherine Parr]] || 1512 – 1548 || || <ref name=Parr /> |- | [[Andrew Perne]] || 1519 – 1589 || Bequeathed his collection to the [[Fitzwilliam Museum]] || <ref name=Fitzwilliam>{{cite journal|last1=Cloke|first1=Christian|title=Coin Collecting at Cambridge: The Fitzwilliam Museum Department of Coins and Medals|journal=[[American Numismatic Society|ANS Magazine]]|date=2008|volume=7|issue=3|url=http://ansmagazine.com/Winter08/Fitzwilliam|accessdate=14 May 2015}}</ref> |- | [[Alessandro Farnese (cardinal)|Alessandro Farnese]] || 1520 – 1589 || Owner of the [[Farnese collection]] || <ref name=answers>{{cite web|title=The Most Famous Coin Collectors of All Time|url=http://coincollecting.answers.com/history/the-most-famous-coin-collectors-of-all-time|accessdate=27 April 2015}}</ref> |- | [[Albert V, Duke of Bavaria]] || 1528 – 1579 || Collection is in the [[Munich Residenz|Bavarian State Coin Collection]] || <ref>{{cite web|last1=Kampmann|first1=Ursula|title=Munich, the German Mecca for Coin Collectors|url=http://www.coinsweekly.com/en/Archive/8?&id=15&type=a|website=Numismata|publisher=Coins Weekly|accessdate=17 July 2015}}</ref> |- | [[Ferdinand II, Archduke of Austria]] || 1529 – 1595 || The cabinets in which he stored his coins are today kept in the Vienna Coin Cabinet and at [[Ambras Castle]] || <ref name=Kunsthistorisches /> |- | [[Abraham Gorlaeus]] || 1549 – 1608 || His collection of 30,000 coins and medals was purchased by [[Henry Frederick, Prince of Wales]] || <ref name=Utility /> |- | [[Wenceslas Cobergher]] || 1560 – 1634 || Collected Roman coins || <ref>{{cite book|last1=Germonprez|first1=Dagmar|title=Foundation, Dedication and Consecration in Early Modern Europe|chapter=Foundation Rites in the Southern Netherlands: Constructing a Counter-Reformational Architecture|date=2011|page=285|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r7p2l48O2KoC&pg=PA285|accessdate=17 July 2015|isbn=9004217576}}</ref> |- | [[Sir Robert Cotton, 1st Baronet, of Connington|Robert Cotton]] || 1571 – 1631 || Collection is in the [[British Museum]] || <ref name=British>{{cite web|title=History of the collection: Coins and Medals|url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/about_us/departments/coins_and_medals/history_of_the_collection.aspx|publisher=[[British Museum]]|accessdate=14 July 2015}}</ref> |- | [[Henry Frederick, Prince of Wales]] || 1594 – 1612 || Purchased [[Abraham Gorlaeus]]' collection || <ref name=Utility /> |- | [[Ernest I, Duke of Saxe-Gotha]] || 1601 – 1675 || || <ref name=Kampmann>{{cite web|last1=Kampmann|first1=Ursula|title=Numismatics in Gotha|url=http://www.coinsweekly.com/en/News/4?&id=1644|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref> |- | [[John Greaves]] || 1602 – 1652 || Left his coins, "which he had collected in Italy and the East," to [[Sir John Marsham, 1st Baronet|Sir John Marsham]] || <ref>{{cite book|last1=Birch|first1=Thomas|author-link=Thomas Birch|chapter=An Historical and Critical Account of the Life and Writings of Mr. John Greaves|title=Miscellaneous Works of Mr. John Greaves|date=1737|location=London|page=lviii|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LstOAAAAcAAJ&pg=PR58|accessdate=18 May 2015}}</ref> |- | [[Louis XIV of France]] || 1638 – 1715 || Said to have instructed his ambassadors to look out for ancient coins. || <ref name=GIM /> |- | [[Jacob de Wilde]] || 1645 – 1721 || || <ref>{{cite book|last1=Wes|first1=Marinus Antony|title=Classics in Russia 1700-1855: Between Two Bronze Horsemen|date=1992|publisher=[[Brill Publishers|Brill]]|page=13|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N9wviNiWb0EC&pg=PA13|accessdate=12 July 2015|isbn=9004096647}}</ref> |- | [[Frederick I, Duke of Saxe-Gotha-Altenburg]] || 1646 – 1691 || His diaries reveal that he "enjoyed making an inventory of his coins and arranging them in order"|| <ref name=Kampmann /> |- | [[Antoine Galland]] || 1646 – 1715 || Purchased ancient coins on his visits to the Middle East|| <ref>{{cite book|last1=Mahdi|first1=Muhsin|author-link=Muhsin Mahdi|title=The Thousand and One Nights|date=1995|publisher=[[Brill Publishers|Brill]]|page=14|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6C2sZFjrhSgC&pg=PA14|accessdate=16 October 2016}}</ref> |- | [[Anton Günther II, Count of Schwarzburg-Sondershausen-Arnstadt]] || 1653 – 1716 || Sold his collection to raise the money needed to become an [[Imperial Prince]] || <ref name=Kampmann /> |- | [[Thomas Herbert, 8th Earl of Pembroke]] || 1656 – 1733 || Collection auctioned in 1848 with 1500 lots || <ref>{{cite book|title=Catalogue of the Entire Pembroke Collection of Greek, Roman, English, Scotch, Irish and Foreign Mediæval Coins and Medals|date=1848|publisher=J. Davy & Sons|location=London|url=http://www.georgebayntun.com/Book.aspx?ID=2652|accessdate=14 May 2015}}</ref> |- | [[Hans Sloane]] || 1660 – 1753 || Collection is in the [[British Museum]] || <ref name=British /> |- | [[Roger Gale (antiquary)|Roger Gale]] || 1672 – 1744 || Bequeathed his collection to the [[Fitzwilliam Museum]] || <ref name=Fitzwilliam /> |- | [[Richard Mead]] || 1653 – 1754 || Collection auctioned in 1755 || <ref>{{cite book|last1=Langford|first1=Abraham|author-link=Abraham Langford|title= Museum Meadianum sive Catalogus Nummorum, Veteris Aevi Monumentorum, ac Gemmarum, Cum aliis quibusdam Artis recentioris et Naturae Operibus; Quae Vir Clariffimus Richardus Mead, M. D. Nuper defenctus comparavet.|date=1755}}</ref> |- | [[Frederick II, Duke of Saxe-Gotha-Altenburg]] || 1676 – 1732 || Purchased collection of [[Anton Günther II, Count of Schwarzburg-Sondershausen-Arnstadt]] || <ref name=Kampmann /> |- | [[George II of Great Britain]] || 1683 – 1760 || Purchased [[Andrew Gifford]]'s collection || <ref name=West>{{cite journal|last1=West|first1=Morris|title=The Bristol 1526 Tyndale Testament - its Origin and its History|journal=[[Reformation (journal)|Reformation]]|date=1996|volume=1|url=http://www.tyndale.org/reformj01/west.html|accessdate=14 May 2015}}</ref> |- | [[William Stukeley]] || 1687 – 1765 || || <ref>{{DNB|prescript=|wstitle=Stukeley, William|last=Wroth|first=Warwick William|authorlink=Warwick William Wroth}}</ref> |- | [[Edward Harley, 2nd Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer]] || 1689 – 1741 || Collected Greek, Roman and English coins; collection auctioned in 1742 || <ref name=Hill>{{cite web|last1=Hill|first1=Jonathan A.|title=Catalogue 190|url=https://www.ilab.org/catalog_view/183/183_190internet.pdf|accessdate=22 May 2015}}</ref> |- | [[Joseph Ames (author)|Joseph Ames]] || 1689 – 1759 || || <ref>{{DNB|prescript=|wstitle=Ames, Joseph (1689-1759)|last=Tedder|first=Henry Richard}}</ref> |- | [[Martin Folkes]] || 1690 – 1754 || Collection auctioned in 1756 || <ref>{{cite book|last1=Langford|first1=Abraham|author-link=Abraham Langford|title=A catalogue of the genuine, entire and choice collection of coins, medals, and medallions: In Gold, Silver, and Brass, Of the Learned and Ingenious Martin Folkes, Esq; Late President of the Royal Society, Deceas'd|date=1756}}</ref> |- | [[Thomas Martin of Palgrave]] || 1697 – 1771 || || <ref>{{cite web|last1=Stoker|first1=David|title=The ill-gotten library of 'Honest Tom' Martin|url=http://users.aber.ac.uk/das/texts/martin.htm|accessdate=14 May 2015}}</ref> |- | [[William Richardson (antiquary)|William Richardson]] || 1698 – 1775 || Collected British, Roman, and English coins || <ref>{{DNB|prescript=|wstitle=Richardson, William (1698-1775)|first=William Prideaux|last=Courtney}}</ref> |- | [[Andrew Gifford]] || 1700 – 1784 || Collection purchased by [[George II of Great Britain|George II]] || <ref name=West /> |- | [[Pieter Teyler van der Hulst]] || 1702 – 1778 || Collection formed the basis of the [[Teylers Coin and Medal Room|Coin and Medal Room]] of the [[Teylers Museum]] || <ref>{{cite web|title=Coins and Medals|url=http://www.teylersmuseum.nl/en/collection/coins-and-medals|publisher=[[Teylers Museum]]|accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref> |- | [[George North (numismatist)|George North]] || 1707 – 1772 || Collected English coins || <ref>{{DNB|prescript=|wstitle=North, George (1710-1772)|last=Wroth|first=Warwick William|authorlink=Warwick William Wroth}}</ref> |- | [[Francis I, Holy Roman Emperor|Francis I]] || 1708 – 1765 || His collecting emphasized modern coins || <ref name=Kunsthistorisches /> |- | [[Louis Günther II, Prince of Schwarzburg-Rudolstadt]] || 1708 – 1790 || || <ref>{{cite web|last1=Winker|first1=Doreen|title=Die Münz- und Medaillensammlung|url=http://www.museum-digital.de/thue/documents/MUENZMEDAILLENSAMMLUNG.pdf|website=museum-digital Thüringen|accessdate=17 July 2015|language=German}}</ref> |- | [[Andrew Ducarel]] || 1713 – 1785 || Collection auctioned in 1785 || <ref>{{cite book|last1=Gerard|first1=John|title=A catalogue of the valuable collection of coins, medals, and antiquities, of that great and well-known antiquary Andrew Coltee Ducarel, LL. D. Deceased|date=1785}}</ref> |- | [[Charlotte Sophie of Aldenburg]] || 1715 – 1800 || Collected Greek and Roman coins || <ref name=Hill /> |- | [[Andrew Eliot]] || 1718 – 1778 || Collected [[Massachusetts pound|New England silver coins]] || <ref>{{cite book|last1=Bowers|first1=Q. David|author-link=Q. David Bowers|title=Coins & Collectors|date=2014|page=277}}</ref> |- | [[William Hunter (anatomist)|William Hunter]] || 1718 – 1783 || Established the [[Hunter Coin Cabinet]] in the [[University of Glasgow]] || <ref name=answers /> |- | [[Charles Watson-Wentworth, 2nd Marquess of Rockingham]] || 1730 – 1782 || Collected Roman imperial coins || <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hopper|first1=R. Holm Collection|url=http://www.ntnu.no/vitenskapsmuseet/sng|publisher=[[NTNU Museum of Natural History and Archaeology]]|accessdate=17 May 2015|language=Norwegian}}</ref> |- | [[Eric P. Newman]] || born 1911 || Collection sold over five auctions in 2013–2014 for almost $55 million || <ref>{{cite web|title=Newman Collection Part V Realizes $10.4+ Million|url=http://www.coinnews.net/2014/11/25/newman-collection-part-v-realizes-10-4-million/|website=CoinNews.net|accessdate=7 July 2015}}</ref> |- | [[John Jay Pittman]] || 1913 – 1996 || President of A.N.A. 1971-73 and C.N.A., massive collection of high-quality US and World gold and silver coins sold by David Akers in auctions from 1997-99 || <ref>{{cite book|last1=Obituary|title=The Numismatist|date=1996|pages=474–475}}</ref>
|- | [[Farouk of Egypt|Farouk I of Egypt]] || 1920 – 1965 || Collection included a [[1933 double eagle]], and was sold by auction for a fraction of its real value in 1954 after Farouk's overthrow || <ref name=GIM>{{cite web|title=Famous Coin Collectors|url=http://gibmint.com/index.php/famous-coin-collectors|publisher=Gibraltar International Mint|accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goldrushgallery.com/news/gumshoe.html |title=Numismatic "Gumshoe:" On the Trail of King Farouk |first=Carl N. |last=Lester |publisher=Gold Rush Gallery}}</ref> |- | [[Arthur W. Hummel, Jr.]] || 1920 – 2001 || Inherited collection of Chinese coins from his father [[Arthur W. Hummel, Sr.]] || <ref name=Album /> |- | [[Chris Schenkel]] || 1923 – 2005 || Collection auctioned in 1990 with 3404 lots || <ref>{{cite book|title=The Chris Schenkel Collection|date=1990|publisher=Bowers and Merena}}</ref> |- | [[Russell Rulau]] || 1926 – 2012 || Coined the term "[[exonumia]]" || <ref>{{cite web|title=TAMS Frequently Asked Questions|url=http://www.tokenandmedal.org/page1/page1.html|publisher=Token and Medal Society|accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref> |- | [[Nelson Bunker Hunt]] || 1926 – 2014 || Collected Greek and Roman coins; collection auctioned off in 1990 and 1991 as a result of his bankruptcy || <ref name=Galloway>{{cite news|last1=Galloway|first1=Paul|title=Bankrupt Hunt Brothers Bid Adieu To Art Collections Worth Millions|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1990-05-10/features/9002070679_1_silver-market-william-herbert-hunt-bunker-and-herbert|accessdate=11 May 2015|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=10 May 1990}}</ref><ref name=Stevenson>{{cite news|last1=Stevenson|first1=Jed|title=Coins|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/09/news/coins.html|accessdate=11 May 2015|work=[[New York Times]]|date=9 June 1991}}</ref> |- | [[Jerome Remick]] || 1928 – 2005 || Edited ''The Guide Book and Catalogue of the British Commonwealth Coins''; established the [[Royal Canadian Numismatic Association]]'s Jerome H. Remick III Literary Award in 1995|| <ref>{{cite web|title=JÉRÔME HOSMER RÉMICK III ( 1928 – 2005 )|url=http://www.canadiangeologicalfoundation.org/Remick.html|publisher=Canadian Geological Foundation|accessdate=14 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Jerome H. Remick III Literary Award|url=http://www.rcna.ca/remick.php|publisher=[[Royal Canadian Numismatic Association]]|accessdate=14 May 2015}}</ref> |- | [[Harry W. Bass, Jr.]] || 1927 – 1998 || Collection resides in the [[American Numismatic Association]] Money Museum || <ref>{{cite web|last1=Bucki|first1=James|title=Top 5 Famous Coin Collections of All Time|url=https://www.thespruce.com/top-famous-coin-collections-768238|publisher=The Spruce|accessdate=25 March 2017}}</ref> |- | [[Kenneth Bressett]] || born 1928 || Collects Chinese and Japanese coins as well as ancient Greek silver coins || <ref>{{cite web|last1=Garrett|first1=Jeff|title=Ten Questions for Numismatic Legend, Ken Bressett|url=http://www.coinweek.com/people-in-the-news/ten-questions-numismatic-legend-ken-bressett/|publisher=Coin Week|accessdate=3 July 2015}}</ref> |- | [[David Gee (forger)|David Gee]] || 1929 – 2013 || Collected [[Coins of Australia|Australian coins]] || <ref>{{cite news|title=Coin dealer found guilty|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/121159867/|accessdate=5 December 2016|work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=20 January 1979}}</ref> |- | [[William Herbert Hunt]] || born 1929 || Collected [[Byzantine coinage|Byzantine coins]]; collection auctioned off in 1990 and 1991 as a result of his bankruptcy || <ref name=Galloway /><ref name=Stevenson /> |- | [[Jerry Buss]] || 1933 – 2013 || Owned a [[1913 Liberty Head nickel]] and an [[1804 dollar]] || <ref>{{cite news|last1=Alpert|first1=Don|title=Buss Rolls Out the Rarities for Auction|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1985-01-17/news/vw-7944_1_sesquicentennial-half-dollar|accessdate=11 May 2015|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=17 January 1985}}</ref> |- | [[Q. David Bowers]] || born 1938 || Began collecting at age 13 and became a coin dealer at age 14 || <ref>{{cite web|last1=Reiter|first1=Ed|title=Q. David Bowers: A One - Man Library|url=http://www.pcgs.com/News/Q-David-Bowers-A-One-Man-Library|publisher=[[Professional Coin Grading Service]]|accessdate=30 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Bowers|first1=Q. David|title=How Q. David Bowers Began Collecting Coins|url=http://www.pcgs.com/News/How-Q-David-Bowers-Began-Collecting-Coins|publisher=[[Professional Coin Grading Service]]|accessdate=30 May 2015}}</ref> |- | [[Walter J. Husak]] || born 1942 || Collection of 301 large cents auctioned in 2008 for $10.7 million || <ref>{{cite news|last1=Rosenblatt|first1=Susannah|last2=Rubin|first2=Joel|title=Collection of rare pennies fetches $10.7 million|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/la-me-pennies17feb17-story.html|accessdate=3 July 2015|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=17 February 2008}}</ref> |- | [[Gregg Bingham]] || born 1951 || Owned an extensive collection of [[Early United States commemorative coins|commemorative half dollars]] and a complete collection of [[Morgan dollar]]s || <ref>{{cite web|title=NGC Certifies Bingham Collection of U.S. Commemoratives|url=http://www.ngccoin.com/news/viewarticle.aspx?NewsletterNewsArticleID=328|publisher=[[Numismatic Guaranty Corporation]]|accessdate=28 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Ganz|first1=David L.|title=Insider's Report|url=http://www.numismedia.com/insider/00-12.shtml|accessdate=28 April 2015}}</ref> |- | [[Andre Dawson]] || born 1954 || Collection auctioned in 1998 for over $6 million || <ref>{{cite web|title=Long Beach Provides Opportunities for Most Dealers|url=http://www.numismedia.com/articles/oct0198.shtml|accessdate=28 April 2015}}</ref> |- | [[Paul Hollis]] || born 1972 || Began collecting at the age of six || <ref>{{cite web|title=Paul Hollis to Announce Candidacy – Louisiana Coin Dealer Running for U.S. Senate|url=http://www.coinnews.net/2008/05/06/louisana-coin-dealer-running-for-us-senate-4075/|website=CoinNews.net|accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref> |}

revision.text:
{{Infobox nobility |name =Mabel Digby |title ='''Lady of Dromana and Decies''' |spouse =Sir Gerald FitzGerald, Lord of Dromana and Decies
Donagh O'Brien |issue =Sir John FitzGerald, Lord of Dromana and Decies
Lettice FitzGerald
Unnamed daughter |birth_date=Sometime after 1598 |birth_place=Coleshill, [[Warwickshire]], England |noble family =[[FitzGerald]] |death_date =Unknown |death_place=Dromana, [[County Waterford]], Ireland |father =Sir Robert Digby |mother =[[Lettice Digby, 1st Baroness Offaly|Lettice FitzGerald]] |}} '''Mabel Digby, Lady of Dromana and Decies''' (dates of birth and death unknown) was an [[Anglo-Irish]] noblewoman being the eldest daughter of [[Robert Digby (courtier)|Sir Robert Digby]] and [[Lettice Digby, 1st Baroness Offaly|Lettice FitzGerald, 1st Baroness Offaly]]. She was the wife of Sir Gerald FitzGerald, Lord of Dromana and Decies. In 1642, during an Irish rebellion, she was openly sympathetic to the Irish and entertained them at Dromana Castle. She later handed the castle over to them.Public Record Office of Northern Ireland, Villiers-Stuart papers, p.6, retrieved 22-12-09 == Family == Mabel was born on an unknown date sometime after 1598 in Coleshill, [[Warwickshire]], England, the eldest daughter and one of the ten children of [[Robert Digby (courtier)|Sir Robert Digby]] and Lettice FitzGerald, ''suo jure'' 1st Baroness Offaly. Her eldest brother was [[Robert Digby, 1st Baron Digby]], and another brother was Essex Digby, [[Bishop of Dromore]]. == Marriages and issue == She married her first husband Sir Gerald FitzGerald, Lord of Dromana and Decies on an unknown date. He was the son and heir of Sir John Og FitzGerald, Lord of Dromana and Decies, and Elinor Butler. She was described as having been "suitably English and [[Protestant]]".Julian Walton, ''Dromana: Lords of Decies and Villiers-Stuarts'', p.6, retrieved 22-12-09 She was said to have dominated Sir Gerald.Public Record Office of Northern Ireland They made their principal residence at Dromana Castle, County Waterford, and together had three children: * Sir John FitzGerald, Lord of Dromana and Decies (died 1 March 1664), married firstly Katherine Le Poer, by whom he had his only daughter and heiress [[Katherine FitzGerald, Viscountess Grandison]]; he married secondly, Helen McCarthy * Lettice FitzGerald, married [[Roundhead|Parliamentarian]] Major Richard Franklyn of Coolbach * Daughter whose name is unknown, married Thomas Walsh of Piltown, Co. Waterford Upon the death of her husband on 6 August 1643, Mabel married secondly Donagh O'Brien of Arragh. == Rebellion of 1641 == On 23 October 1641, a major Irish rebellion broke out in [[Ulster]], and by December had spread to [[County Waterford]]. (See main article: [[Irish rebellion of 1641]]). Although her husband sided with the English, Mabel showed herself sympathetic to the Irish rebels and in 1642 entertained them at Dromana Castle serving them "beefes, muttons, bread and beere".Public Record Office of Northern Ireland, p.6 In mid-September 1642, she handed the castle over to them; however, it was shortly afterward besieged and captured by the English. == Death == Mabel died on an unknown date at Dromana. Her granddaughter, Katherine, inherited the entire Dromana estate upon the death of Mabel's only son in 1664. The FitzGeralds had managed to keep their estates intact during the [[Oliver Cromwell|Cromwellian]] settlements due to their Protestant religion and the influence of Mabel's Parliamentarian son-in-law Richard Franklyn, who served as a major in Oliver Cromwell's army. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Digby, Mabel}} [[Category:FitzGerald dynasty]] [[Category:Anglo-Irish people]] [[Category:People from Warwickshire]] [[Category:People from County Waterford]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Year of death unknown]] [[Category:17th-century women]] [[Category:Digby family]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox saint |name= Blessed Michael Sopoćko |birth_date= 1 November 1888 |birth_place= [[Nowosady, Hajnówka County|Juszewszczyzna]], [[Ashmyany]], [[Poland]] |death_date= {{death date and age|1975|02|15|1888|11|01|df=yes}} |death_place= [[Białystok]], Poland |image= Sopoćko.jpg |caption= Father Michał Sopoćko |titles=Priest |venerated=[[Roman Catholic Church]] |feast=15 February |attributes=[[Cassock]] |patronage=Białystok{{cite web|url=http://wpolityce.pl/spoleczenstwo/279587-blogoslawiony-ks-sopocko-bedzie-patronem-bialegostoku|title=Blessed Father Sopocko will be the patron of Bialystok|publisher=wPolityce|date=|accessdate=29 January 2016}} |beatified_date=28 September 2008 |beatified_place=Białystok, Poland |beatified_by=Cardinal [[Angelo Amato]] }} {{Divine Mercy}} [[Beatification|Blessed]] '''Michael''' (in Polish: '''Michał''') '''Sopoćko''' ({{IPAc-pl|mʲ|i|ˈ|h|a|ł|-|ˈ|s|o|p|o|ć|k|o}}; November 1, 1888 – February 15, 1975) was a [[Roman Catholic]] priest and professor at [[Vilnius University]].{{sfn|Odell, pp. 84-85}} He is best known as the spiritual director of Saint [[Faustina Kowalska]]. ==Life== He was born in 1888 in Juszewszczyzna (also known as Nowosady) near [[Valozhyn]] in present-day [[Belarus]].[http://www.vatican.va/news_services/liturgy/saints/2008/ns_lit_doc_20080928_sopocko_en.html Vatican biography of Michał Sopoćko] He entered [[Vilnius Priest Seminary]] in 1910 and was ordained in 1914. He was a priest in Vilnius (1914–1918), then a chaplain in the army in Warsaw and Vilnius during [[World War I]]. After obtaining his doctorate in theology in 1926 he became the spiritual director at the seminary in Vilnius. and 1928 professor of pastoral theology at [[Stefan Batory University]] in Vilnius. ==Divine Mercy== [[File:Lomza Holycross fc03.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Paintings of Faustina and Sopoćko in [[Łomża]]]] Father Sopoćko was very supportive of the [[Divine Mercy]] devotion of Faustina Kowalska and in her diary (Notebook V, item 1238) she stated: "This priest is a great soul, entirely filled with God." Since 1931 Faustina had been trying (without success) to find someone to paint the ''[[Divine Mercy image]]'' until Sopoćko became her confessor in the middle of 1933. By January 1934 Sopocko arranged for the artist [[Eugeniusz Kazimirowski]] (who was also a professor at the university) to paint the image.{{sfn|Torretto, pp. 84-107}}Odell, Catherine M. ''Faustina: Apostle of Divine Mercy''. OSV Press, 1998 ({{ISBN|978-0-87973-923-2}}), 85-95 On Friday April 26, 1935 Sopoćko delivered the first sermon ever on the Divine Mercy - and Faustina attended the sermon.{{sfn|Torretto, p. 16}} The first Mass during which the [[Divine Mercy image]] was displayed was on April 28, 1935, the [[Divine Mercy Sunday]] (the first after Easter). Sopoćko managed to obtain permission to place the [[Divine Mercy image]] within the [[Gate of Dawn]] in [[Vilnius]] as he celebrated the Mass that Sunday.{{sfn|Torretto, p. 16}}{{sfn|Odell, pp. 102-103}} In the summer of 1936 Sopoćko wrote the first brochure on the [[Divine Mercy]] devotion and obtained the [[imprimatur]] of [[Romuald Jałbrzykowski|Archbishop Jałbrzykowski]] for it. The brochure carried the Divine Mercy image on the cover.{{sfn|Odell, p. 119}} Faustina used to regard him as a saint: ''This priest is a great soul who is completely filled with God'' (''Diary'' 1238). ''Thanks to his effort a new light will shine in God's Church for the salvation of souls. […] I have not met such faithfulness to God as this soul features'' (1390). ''This soul, so humble, was able to withstand all storms and has not get discouraged with obstacles, but answered faithfully to God's call'' (1586). Jesus used to have similar opinion: ''This is a priest according to My heart; his efforts are pleasant to Me. […] Through him I disseminate consolations for suffering, worried souls; through him I have been well pleased to proclaim the worship to My mercy'' (1256). ''His thought is closely connected with My thought, so be calm about My work; I will not allow him to mistake, and you, do not do anything without his permission'' (1408). ==[[Congregation of Sisters of Merciful Jesus]]== In 1942, during [[World War II]] Sopoćko and other professors and students had to go into hiding near Vilnius for about two years. However, he used this time to establish a new religious congregation based on the [[Divine Mercy]] messages reported by [[Faustina Kowalska]]. After the War, Sopoćko wrote the constitution for the congregation and helped the formation of what is now [[Zgromadzenie Sióstr Jezusa Miłosiernego]]. In an entry in [[Diary: Divine Mercy in My Soul|her diary]] on February 8, 1935, (Notebook I, item 378) Faustina had written that the Divine Mercy devotion would be suppressed for some time after her death, but would be accepted again, although Sopoćko would suffer for it.Tim Drake, 2002, ''Saints of the Jubilee'', {{ISBN|978-1-4033-1009-5}}, pp. 85-95Catherine M. Odell, 1998, ''Faustina: Apostle of Divine Mercy'', OSV Press, {{ISBN|978-0-87973-923-2}}, pp. 153-160 In 1959 the Vatican forbade the Divine Mercy devotion and censured Sopoćko.''An Anthology of Christian mysticism'' by Harvey D. Egan, 1991, {{ISBN|0-8146-6012-6}}, pp. 563-565 But in 1965 [[Karol Wojtyła]], then Archbishop of Kraków and later Pope John Paul II opened a new investigation and submitted documents in 1968, which resulted in the reversal of the ban in 1978. After the [[Second World War]], when the boundaries of Poland changed so much, Sopoćko left Vilnius. Until 1962 he has been a professor of pastoral theology at the [[seminary]] in [[Białystok]]. That time he wrote a book ''Miłosierdzie Boga w dziełach Jego'' (''Mercy of God in His works'') in four volumes. He died on February 15, 1975 in [[Białystok]], [[People's Republic of Poland|Poland]], and was buried there. In 1988 his remains were transferred to the Church of Divine Mercy in [[Osiedle Białostoczek, Białystok|Białostoczek]]. ==Quote==
The decisive factor in obtaining God’s Mercy is trust. Trust is the expectation of someone’s help. It does not constitute a separate virtue, but is an essential condition of the virtue of hope, and an integral part of the virtues of fortitude and generosity. Because trust springs from faith, it strengthens hope and love, and is, moreover, linked up, in one way or another, with the moral virtues. It may, therefore, be called the basis on which the theological virtues unite with the moral. The moral virtues, originally natural, become supernatural if we practice them with trust in God’s help.[http://www.gla.ac.uk/services/catholicchaplaincy/divinemercy/miracles/ Sopocko, Michael, "Trust in God", Catholic Chaplaincy, University of Glasgow]
==Veneration== His case for [[beatification]] was started at the Vatican in 1987.{{sfn|Odell, pp. 84-85}} In 2004, [[Pope John Paul II]] issued a decree on the virtues of Father Sopoćko.''Purest of All Lilies: The Virgin Mary in the Spirituality of St. Faustina'' by Donald H. Calloway, 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-59614-195-7}}, p. 29 In December 2007, Pope [[Benedict XVI]] approved of a miracle through his intercession. His solemn beatification took place on Sunday September 28, 2008 at the Sanctuary of Divine Mercy in Białystok. ==See also== {{Commons category|Michał Sopoćko}} * [[Divine Mercy]] * [[Divine Mercy image]] * [[Faustina Kowalska]] * [[Józef Andrasz]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Sources== * Odell, Catherine M. ''Faustina: The Apostle of Divine Mercy''. 1998 ({{ISBN|0-87973-923-1}}). * Torretto, Richard. "The Image of Divine Mercy", ''A Divine Mercy Resource''. 2010 ({{ISBN|1-4502-3236-1}}). {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sopocko, Michal}} [[Category:1888 births]] [[Category:1975 deaths]] [[Category:Polish beatified people]] [[Category:Polish Roman Catholic priests]] [[Category:Vilnius University faculty]] [[Category:Białystok]] [[Category:Catholic devotions]] [[Category:Religious leaders]] [[Category:Visions of Jesus and Mary]] [[Category:Belarusian people]] [[Category:Divine Mercy]] [[Category:20th-century venerated Christians]] [[Category:Beatifications by Pope Benedict XVI]] [[Category:Venerated Catholics by Pope John Paul II]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{distinguish|Mr. Natwarlal}} '''Mithilesh Kumar Srivastava''', better known as '''Natwarlal''' (1912–2009),<ref name=ht/><ref name=nan/> was a noted [[India]]n [[Confidence trick|con man]] known for having repeatedly "sold" the [[Taj Mahal]], the [[Red Fort]], and the [[Rashtrapati Bhavan]] and also the [[Sansad Bhavan|Parliament House of India]] along with its sitting members.<ref name=ht/><ref name=zn/><ref>{{cite book|title=Applied Psychology: India Specific and Cross-cultural Perspectives By Smarak Swain|pages=22|url=https://books.google.com/?id=VA9TaE2V0eMC&pg=PA22&lpg=PA22&dq=natwarlal+shrivastav#v=onepage&q=natwarlal%20shrivastav&f=false}}</ref>
==Earlier life== He was born in village in siwan, by profession he was a lawyer before he became a [[con man]].<ref name=nan>{{cite news|title=Nuts about Natwarlal|url=http://www.timescrest.com/opinion/nuts-about-natwarlal-5243|accessdate=3 August 2018|newspaper=The Times of India|date=23 April 2018}}</ref>
==Modus operandi== He duped hundreds of people of [[crore]]s of rupees and used more than 50 aliases to disguise himself.<ref name=ht/> He was a master of disguises and used novel ideas to cheat people. He was also a master in forging signatures of famous personalities.<ref name=ht/><ref name=nan/> He is also said to have cheated a number of industrialists including the [[Tata family|Tatas]], the [[Birla family|Birlas]] and also [[Dhirubhai Ambani]]<ref name=cl/> taking from them huge sums of money in cash, posing as a social worker or needy person.<ref name=cl>[[Chitralekha (weekly)|Chitralekha]], Feb 2007</ref> He also duped many shop-owners of [[lakh]]s of rupees, paying them by [[cheque]] and [[demand draft]]s, which were later found to be forged.<ref name=nan/><ref name=cl/>
Natwarlal was wanted in more than 100 cases and by the police of 8 states.<ref>{{cite news|title=Famous Fugitives|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/oldStory/41442/|accessdate=3 August 2012|newspaper=[[Indian Express]]|date=20 February 2004}}</ref>
Natwarlal was arrested nine times but every time he was able to break out of jail and escape. He was convicted for 14 cases of forgery and was sentenced for 113 years, but he hardly spent 20 years in prison.<ref>{{cite news |last=Madhavan |first=Deepu |url=http://www.indiatimes.com/news/india/10-things-you-need-to-know-about-the-man-who-sold-the-taj-mahal-thrice-247513.html |title=10 Things You Need To Know About The Man Who Sold The Taj Mahal. Thrice!!! |work=[[India Times]] |date=2015-11-19 |accessdate=2016-01-02 }}</ref>The last time he was arrested was in 1996 and was 84 years old at that time. But he managed again to give the police the slip and was last seen by authorities on June 24, 1996; when the wheelchair-using octogenarian vanished while being transported from prison to a hospital for treatment. He disappeared at [[New Delhi]] railway station, when he was being taken to [[AIIMS]], under police escort from [[Kanpur]] jail for his treatment,<ref name=ht/><ref name=nan/> after which he was never seen again.<ref name=ht/><ref name=nan/>
==Death and mystery== In 2009, his lawyer requested that more than 100 charges pending against Natwarlal be dropped claiming that Natwarlal died on Saturday July 25, 2009. However, Natwarlal's brother, Ganga Prasad Srivastava, subsequently claimed to have [[cremated]] him in 1996 at [[Ranchi]].<ref name=ht>{{cite news|title=Natwarlal leaves ’em guessing even in death|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india/natwarlal-leaves-em-guessing-even-in-death/story-mYkqbv8grOOw0oFEsIryrJ.html|accessdate=3 August 2012|newspaper=[[Hindustan Times]]|date=29 July 2009}}</ref><ref name=zn/> So the actual time and year of death is yet uncertain. In the finest Natwarlal fashion, he “died” twice, 13 years apart, living up to his legend.
He had 2 wives. He is survived by one daughter, who lives in Ranchi and is married to a soldier.<ref name=nan/> His younger brother, Ganga Prasad Shrivastav lives in [[Gopalganj (Bihar)|Gopalganj]].<ref name=nan/>
==In popular culture== His exploits are often compared with [[Frank Abagnale]]<ref name=toi>{{cite news|title=Gotcha|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2007-04-01/special-report/27868558_1_max-domarus-hitler-s-speeches-adolf-hitler|accessdate=3 August 2012|newspaper=[[Times of India]]|date=1 April 2007}}</ref> and [[Victor Lustig]].<ref>[http://www.pitara.com/discover/5wh/online.asp?story=74 Who Sold the Eiffel Tower Twice?]</ref>
''Jurm'' is a popular weekly crime based television programme aired by [[Aaj Tak]], based on episodes of his life and a story that was broadcast in 2004.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aaj Tak bids to unravel mystery of conman Natwarlal|url=http://www.indiantelevision.com/tube/y2k4/apr/aprtube10.htm|accessdate=3 August 2012|newspaper=Indiantelevision.com|date=3 April 2004|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130103032057/http://www.indiantelevision.com/tube/y2k4/apr/aprtube10.htm#|archive-date=2013-01-03|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
==Monument== The people of his native village Bangra in Bihar take pride in the fact that he belonged to their village and have decided to put up a statue of him as his monument, at the place where his house once stood.<ref name=nan/>
While his house is said to have been demolished by the British, the land still belongs to the family.<ref name=nan/>
==Namesake== He is considered to be the greatest conman in Indian history and his legend lives on as any conman who pulls off particularly smart cons is called Natwarlal in India. Many fraudsters say they were inspired by the life of Natwarlal.<ref name=zn>{{cite news|title=Conman inspired by Natwarlal arrested|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/delhi/conman-inspired-by-natwarlal-arrested_691648.html|accessdate=3 August 2012|newspaper=[[Zee News]] |date=6 March 2011}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox musical artist | name = Nego do Borel | image = NegodoBorel.png | imagesize = 280px | caption = Nego do Borel in 2018 | background = solo_singer | alias = | birth_name = Leno Maycon Viana Gomes | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1992|07|10|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Rio de Janeiro]], Brazil | death_date = | genre = {{flatlist| *[[Funk melody]] *[[funk carioca]] *[[pop music|pop]] *[[Freestyle music|freestyle]] *[[funk ostentação]]}} | occupation = {{flatlist| *[[Singer]] *[[songwriter]] *[[actor]]}} | years_active = {{flatlist| *2012–present {{small|(singer)}} *2015–present {{small|(actor)}} }} | label = [[Sony Music]] | associated_acts = {{flatlist| *[[Anitta (singer)|Anitta]] *[[Wesley Safadão]] *[[Maluma (singer)|Maluma]] *[[Luan Santana]] *Maiara & Maraísa *[[Lucas Lucco]]}} | website = [http://www.negodoborel.com/ negodoborel.com] }} '''Nego do Borel''', artistic name of '''Leno Maycon Viana Gomes''' (born 10 July 1992) is Brazilian singer of [[funk ostentação]].[http://ego.globo.com/famosos/noticia/2014/03/mc-nego-do-borel-explode-com-hit-ostentacao-e-quer-se-converter.html ''MC Nego do Borel explode com hit ostentação e quer se converter''] He is known for [[hit record|hits]], "Os Cara do Momento", "Diamante de Lama", "Bonde dos Brabos" and "[[Você Partiu Meu Coração]]" with [[Wesley Safadão]] and [[Anitta (singer)|Anitta]].[http://ego.globo.com/famosos/noticia/2014/08/nego-do-borel-lanca-dvd-em-que-distribui-r-5-mil-durante-show.html ''Nego do Borel lança DVD em que distribui R$ 5 mil durante show''] Currently he has two albums released by [[Sony Music]].[http://jovem.ig.com.br/cultura/musica/2014-03-20/dos-dentes-dentes-podres-mc-nego-do-borel-vira-hit-e-ganha-r-200-mil-por-mes.html ''Dos dentes podres, MC Nego do Borel vira hit e ganha R$ 150 mil por mês''] Nego do Borel was the sixth Brazilian artist to enter the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].[https://headlineplanet.com/home/2018/01/09/maluma-nego-borels-corazon-debuts-billboard-hot-100/ Maluma & Nego do Borel’s “Corazon” Debuts On Billboard Hot 100] == Early life == Leno Maycon Viana Gomes was born on July 10, 1992 in Rio de Janeiro and was raised in Morro do Borel, a slum in Rio. He was the only child of Roseli Vianna and Nelcir Gomes.{{cite web|url = http://globotv.globo.com/rede-globo/tv-xuxa/v/mc-nego-do-borel-tira-plateia-do-chao-com-sucesso-eu-adoro-eu-me-amarro/2734203/|title = Nego do Borel tira plateia do chão com sucesso Eu adoro Eu me amarro|website = Globo TV|accessdate = 20 February 2014 | date = 3 August 2013 | language = Portuguese}} He dropped out of school in fourth grade to become a funk artist.{{cite web |url= http://jovem.ig.com.br/cultura/musica/2014-03-20/dos-dentes-dentes-podres-mc-negro-do-borel-vira-hit-e-ganha-r-200-mil-por-mes.html |title = Dos dentes dentes podres MC Nego do Borel vira hit e ganha R$ 150 mil por mês |website= Jovem Pan |language= Portuguese}} The name "Nego do Borel" (meaning "black man of Borel") emerged from a nickname given by one of Gomes' friends. Gomes would later adopt it as his stage name.{{cite web|url = http://queromusicaboa.com.br/component/k2/item/download/133_98e232d6785cfa0f43f6c3232df0|title = Nego do Borel, o apelido que logo virou nome artístico|website = QueroMusicaBoa|language = Portuguese}} Nego was raised evangelist and his mother baptised him Leno Maycon Viana Gomes after [[John Lennon]] and [[Michael Jackson]].{{cite web|url = http://ego.globo.com/famosos/noticia/2014/03/mc-nego-do-borel-explode-com-hit-ostentacao-e-quer-se-converter.html|title = MC Nego do Borel explode com hit ostentação e quer se converter|website = Ego|language = Portuguese}} He had almost all of his teeth rotten, being that his first money earned with the music was to take care of his oral health. Nego lived in a poverty situation and got hungry.{{cite web|url = http://ego.globo.com/famosos/noticia/2014/03/mc-nego-do-borel-explode-com-hit-ostentacao-e-quer-se-converter.html|title = MC Nego do Borel explode com hit ostentação e quer se coverter|website = Ego|language = Portuguese}} Nego bought dentures with 100,000 reals and reformed his house for his mother.{{cite web |url= http://jovem.ig.com.br/cultura/musica/2014-03-20/dos-dentes-dentes-podres-mc-nego-do-borel-vira-hit-e-ganha-r-200-mil-por-mes.html |title = Dos dentes dentes MC Nego do Norel vira hit e ganha R$ 150 mil por mês |work= Jovem Pan, jovem.ig.com.br |language= Portuguese}} With the fame at the present, the artist received more than 200,000 reals per month.{{cite web |url= http://entretenimento.r7.com/pop/musica/fotos/ganhando-r200-mil-por-mes-funkeiro-joga-dinheiro-na-plateia-e-pilota-moto-com-nada-em-gravacao-25082014 |title= Ganhado R$ 200 mil por mês, funkeiro-joga dinheiro na plateia e pilota moto com nada em gravaçao-25082014 |website= Entretenimento |language= Portuguese}} == Career == === 2012-2014: Beginning of career === In 2012, Nego released his debut single "Os Caras do Momento" (English: The Guys of the Moment).{{cite web|url = http://jovem.ig.com.br/cultura/musica/2014-03-20/dos-dentes-dentes-podres-mc-nego-do-borel-vira-hit-e-ganha-r-200-mil-por-mes.html|title = MC Nego do Borel vira hit e ganha R$ 150 mil por mês|date = |accessdate=19 November 2018|language = Portuguese}} As of October 2018, the music video has approximately more than 50 million views on YouTube.{{cite web|url = http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NgB6N5_Jw4w|title = MC Nego do Borel - Os Caras do Momento (CLIPE OFICIAL)|date = December 14, 2012}} After his hit single's success, the singer appeared on several television shows such as [[TV Xuxa]], [[Programa do Ratinho]], [[A Liga]], [[Agora É Tarde]], [[The Noite com Danilo Gentili]] and more.{{citation needed|date = November 2018}} Nego do Borel's second single "Bonde dos Brabos" currently has more than 14 million views on YouTube.{{cite web|url = http://ofuxio.com.br/noticias-sobre-famosos/mc-nego-do-borel-lanca-musicas-de-seu-dvd-no-vevo-e-no-youtube|title = MC Nego do Borel lança músicas de seu DVD no VEVO e no YouTube||language = Portuguese}} Nego do Borel was soon signed to Sony Music and released three albums in 2014: the two extended plays ''MC Nego do Borel'', ''É Ele Mesmo'' and the live television DVD ''Da Lama a Ostentação - Ao Vivo''.{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} The first album was released on April 29, 2014 and the second album was released on August 19, 2014.{{cite web|url = http://uol.com.br/album/mc-nego-do-borel/mc-nego-do-borel/135064|title = MC Nego do Borel álbum MC Nego do Borel na Rádio Uol|language = Portuguese}}{{cite web|url =http://amazon.com/Ele-Mesmo-Explicit-Nego-Borel/dp/B00MRZHOFK|title = MC Nego do Borel - É ele mesmo (album), disponível no Amazon|language = Portuguese}} That same year, Nego released the song "Menina Má" from the DVD ''Da Lama a Ostentação'' featuring Melanina Carioca.{{cite web|url = http://purebreak.com.br/noticias/mc-nego-do-borel-lanca-clipe-de-menina-ma-com-melanina-carioca/6292|title = MC Nego do Borel lança clipe de "Menina Má" com Melanina Carioca|language = Portuguese}} ===2015-present: ''Nego Resolve'' and Appearance on TV=== In 2015, Nego do Borel released his first studio album ''Nego Resolve'' which included the singles "Não Me Deixe Sozinho", "Janela Aberta" e "Nego Resolve".{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} Nego collaborated with singer Anitta on her third studio album ''Bang''.{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} == Artistry == === Influences === Nego do Borel cites Brazilian funk carioca singer Menor do Chapa as his biggest influence.{{cite web|url = http://jovem.ig.com.br/cultura/musica/2014-03-20/dos-dentes-dentes-podres-mc-nego-do-borel-vira-hit-e-ganha-r-200-mil-por-mes.html|title = Dos dentes dentes podres MC Nego do Borel vira hit e ganha R$ 150 mil por mês|website = JovemPan|language = Portuguese}} === Alter egos === Nego do Borel portrays the character ''Nega da Boreli'' (meaning "black woman of Boreli"), who caricatures a [[travesti]] from a surburb and claims to be the girlfriend of Nego do Borel.{{cite web|url = http://globotv.globo.com/rede-globo/tv-xuxa/v/mc-nego-do-borel-tira-plateia-do-chao-com-sucesso-eu-adoro-eu-me-amarro/2734203/|title = MC Nego do Borel tira plateia do chao com sucesso eu adoro eu me amarro|language = Portuguese}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== * ''MC Nego do Borel'' (2014) * ''É Ele Mesmo'' (2014) * ''Nego Resolve'' (2015) ===Singles=== ====As lead artist==== {| class="wikitable" !rowspan="2" style="width:14em;"| Title !colspan="1"| Charts !rowspan="2"| Album |- ! scope="col" style="width:4em;font-size:80%;"| [[Brasil Hot 100 Airplay|BRA
Billboard]] |- | "Os Caras do Momento" |align="center"| — |align="center" rowspan="4"| ''MC Nego do Borel''
''&'' ''É Ele Mesmo'' |- | "Bonde dos Brabos" |align="center"| — |- | "Brincadeira das Maravilhas (Eu Adoro, Eu Me Amarro)" |align="center"| — |- | "Diamante de Lama" |align="center"| — |- | "Quero Usufruir" |align="center"| — |align="center" rowspan="1"| ''É Ele Mesmo'' |- | "Menina Má" |align="center"| — |align="center" rowspan="1"| ''Da Lama à Ostentação'' |- |''Não Me Deixe Sozinho'' |align="center"| — |align="center" rowspan="4"| ''Nego Resolve'' |- |''Janela Aberta'' |align="center"| — |- |''Nego Resolve'' |align="center"| — |- | "Pretinha Vou Te Confessar" |align="center"| — |- |"Hoje é Dia de Maldade" |align="center"| — |align="center" rowspan="4" | ''TBA'' |- |"Ela Vai Além" |align="center"| — |- |"[[Você Partiu Meu Coração]]" (feat. [[Anitta (singer)|Anitta]] & [[Wesley Safadão]]) |align="center"| 21 |- |"[[Esqueci Como Namora]]" (feat. [[Maiara e Maraísa]]) |align="center"| 38 |- | colspan="11" style="text-align:center; font-size:8pt;"| "—" denota singles que não entraram nas paradas musicais. |} ====As featured artist==== ==Tours== *''Os Caras Do Momento'' (2014-2015) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website}} * {{Facebook|1=oficialnegodoborel}} * {{Allmusic|http://www.allmusic.com/artist/mc-nego-do-borel-mn0003292273}} * {{Twitter|Negodoborel|MC Nego do Borel}} * {{Discogs artist|4070049-MC-Nego-Do-Borel}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nego do Borel, MC}} [[Category:1992 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Musicians from Rio de Janeiro (city)]] [[Category:Afro-Brazilian people]] [[Category:Brazilian male musicians]] [[Category:Brazilian male singers]] [[Category:Funk carioca musicians]] [[Category:Brazilian pop singers]] [[Category:Brazilian male television actors]] [[Category:Brazilian songwriters]] {{Brazil-singer-stub}}

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} [[File:OlavScheflo.JPG|thumb|upright|Scheflo]] '''Olav Andreas Scheflo''' (9 September 1883 - 25 June 1943) was a [[Norway|Norwegian]] [[Communist]] politician and journalist.
Olav Scheflo was a member of the [[Norwegian Labour Party]] from 1905. After the [[October Revolution]] he fought hard to convince the Labor Party to join the [[Communist International]] and Scheflo was a Norwegian representative at the second congress of the Comintern in 1920 and was member of the Comintern Executive Committee from 1921 to 1927. Critical towards [[Stalinism]], he left the [[Norwegian Communist Party]] in 1928 and rejoined the Labor Party in 1929.
When [[Sweden]]'s Communist leader, [[Zeth Höglund]] was offered to be made honorable corporal in the [[Red Army]] in 1918 but declined, the offer instead went to Scheflo, who gladly accepted the position.
When [[Leon Trotsky]] lived in exile in Norway in 1935 and 1936, Scheflo strongly defended him against attacks from both Stalinist and the Norwegian bourgeoisie. However, he would never become a real [[Trotskyist]]s since he was closer to the Soviet [[Right Opposition]].
Scheflo's autobiography is ''Den røde tråd i Norges historie'' (''The Red Thread in Norwegian History'').
{{Norwegian Labour Party}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Scheflo, Olav}} [[Category:1883 births]] [[Category:1943 deaths]] [[Category:Norwegian communists]] [[Category:Norwegian Comintern people]] [[Category:Comintern people]] [[Category:Executive Committee of the Communist International]]

revision.text:
{{context|date=August 2017}} {{Infobox soap character | series = [[Hollyoaks]] | name = Pete Buchanan |image = Pete Buchanan.jpg |imagesize = 200px | portrayer = [[Kai Owen]] | introducer = [[Bryan Kirkwood (producer)|Bryan Kirkwood]] (2015, 2018) | years = 2015–2016, 2018 | first = 2 June 2015 | last = 12 October 2018 | born = 1975 | classification = [[List of past Hollyoaks characters#Last appeared in 2018|Former; regular]] | occupation= Builder | home = Prison | wife = [[Reenie McQueen|Reenie Buchanan-McQueen]] (2015–2016) | stepdaughters = [[Porsche McQueen]] (2015–2016)
[[Celine McQueen]] (2015–2016)
[[Cleo McQueen]] (2015–2016) }} '''Pete Buchanan''' is a [[Character (arts)|fictional character]] from the [[Television in the United Kingdom|British]] [[Channel 4]] [[soap opera]] ''[[Hollyoaks]]'', played by [[Kai Owen]].{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a648767/eastenders-newbie-corrie-reveal-emmerdale-horror-hollyoaks-turmoil.html#~pdywy0Jg2FocU1|title=EastEnders newbie, Corrie reveal, Emmerdale horror, Hollyoaks turmoil|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|date=24 May 2015|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines UK]]|accessdate=24 May 2015}} Since Pete's arrival he has been involved in the sex abuse plot within the [[McQueen family]]. He made his first appearance on 2 June 2015 and he left the series on 29 June 2016. On 21 September 2018, it was announced that Pete would return for a guest stint. http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/hollyoaks/news/a866734/hollyoaks-spoilers-pete-buchanan-return-cleo-mcqueen-bulimia-story/ ==Creation and development== The concept and name of the character was announced on 8 April 2015,{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s13/hollyoaks/news/a640328/hollyoaks-announces-child-sex-abuse-storyline-for-mcqueen-family.html#~p9haNoeOS0B8fK|title=Hollyoaks announces child sex abuse storyline for McQueen family|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|date=8 April 2015|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines UK]]|accessdate=8 April 2015}} while additional details such as casting was announced on 10 April 2015. Pete is [[Reenie McQueen]]'s ([[Zöe Lucker]]) ex-boyfriend, it is revealed that he [[Child molestation|sexually assaulted]] [[Porsche McQueen]] ([[Twinnie Lee Moore]]) when she was 15 years old and subjected her younger sisters, [[Celine McQueen|Celine]] (Sarah George) and [[Cleo McQueen|Cleo]] ([[Nadine Rose Mulkerrin]]), to varying levels of abuse. Pete is portrayed as "charming and deceptive" as well as "a nice guy" and as such he was able to convince Reenie that Porsche propositioned him at the time of the event. ===Sexual abuse storyline=== It was announced in April 2015 that the McQueen family were going to be centre to a sexual abuse storyline. ''Hollyoaks'' were working with the [[NSPCC]] with the storyline. The NSPCC said "We've teamed-up with ''Hollyoaks'' to highlight the most common form of child sexual abuse with the aim of assisting young victims to find help and support"{{cite web|url=https://www.nspcc.org.uk/fighting-for-childhood/news-opinion/child-sexual-abuse-within-family-latest-hollyoaks-storyline/|title=Child sexual abuse within the family features in latest Hollyoaks storyline|work=[[NSPCC]]|date=8 April 2015|accessdate=29 November 2015}} In early October 2015, it was announced that Pete would face a trial for sexually abusing the McQueen girls.{{cite web|first=Duncan|last=Lindsay|url=http://metro.co.uk/2015/10/02/hollyoaks-spoilers-paedophile-pete-buchanan-for-child-sex-abuse-trial-5418506/|title=Hollyoaks spoilers: Paedophile Pete Buchanan for child sex abuse trial|work=Metro|date=2 October 2015|accessdate=29 November 2015}} On 27 November 2015, it was announced that Pete would have Cleo go and hide a key to a lock up that has photos of him and her but she will find out there is also photos of [[Jade Albright]] (Kassius Nelson).{{cite web |first=Sophie|last=Dainty|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/hollyoaks/news/a775506/hollyoaks-spoilers-cleo-mcqueen-to-realise-the-truth-about-pete-after-reenie-is-arrested/|title=Hollyoaks spoilers: Cleo McQueen will realise the truth about Pete after Reenie is arrested|publisher=Digital Spy|date=27 November 2015|accessdate=29 November 2015}} ==Storylines== Porsche tells Phoebe about how her mother, [[Reenie McQueen|Reenie]] ([[Zöe Lucker]]), was always better when Pete was around, but one night after Reenie came home drunk, Pete sexually assaulted her. It can also be noted that Reenie didn't believe Porsche when she was told about Pete's inappropriate behavior. On the day of [[Phoebe McQueen]]'s (Mandip Gill) funeral, it was revealed that Pete had been molesting Cleo for years.{{cite web|first=Duncan|last=Lindsay|url=http://metro.co.uk/2015/08/13/hollyoaks-spoilers-paedophile-storyline-involving-pete-buchanan-to-end-in-the-right-way-5340655/|title=Hollyoaks spoilers: Paedophile storyline involving Pete Buchanan to 'end in the right way'|work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|date=13 August 2015|accessdate=26 August 2015}} Pete makes his first appearance on 2 June. Porsche emotionally reveals to her family that when she was 15, Pete sexually abused her. Pete claims that Porsche kissed him, but that he rebuffed her advances. Subsequently, nobody believes that Porsche was abused. Pete begins to sexually abuse and groom Porsche's younger sister Cleo after his arrival; although it is implied that he has been doing so for some time before this. When Cleo refuses to continue her "relationship" with him, Pete leaves Reenie, knowing that this will cause Reenie's drinking to spiral out of control. Subsequently, Cleo begs for him to return and he does so on the understanding that she will go along with what he wants. Upon his return he proposes to Reenie, but privately tells Cleo that this is so he can be closer to Cleo. Pete grows extremely jealous of Cleo's relationship with her boyfriend, Harry, even persuading [[Jack Osborne]] ([[Jimmy McKenna]]) to rethink his decision of letting Cleo work for him during the summer. To prevent Cleo from going to see Harry, Pete has sex with Cleo.{{cite web|first=Daniel|last=Kilkelly|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s13/hollyoaks/news/a640816/hollyoaks-casts-torchwood-star-kai-owen-as-abuser-pete.html#~p9rknHkj6K0bnz|title=Hollyoaks casts Torchwood star Kai Owen as abuser Pete|date=10 April 2015|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines UK]]|accessdate=10 April 2015}} At some point Pete doesn't use a [[condom]] when having sex with Cleo and she has to go to the sexual health clinic, which infuriates Porsche, Cleo lies and says she slept with Harry. Later that evening, Reenie and Pete buy Cleo [[birth control]] pills. Weeks later, Pete meets [[Jade Albright]] (Kassius Nelson), who is being fostered by the Osborne family, Pete helps Jade with her schoolwork and gives her a phone so he can start grooming her. Cleo later notices how Pete is acting with Jade and threatens to expose their relationship to Reenie. On the week of Pete and Reenie's wedding, Cleo is ready to expose her and Pete's relationship with Reenie when Pete makes Cleo believe that Reenie has terminal breast cancer. After Cleo learns this is a lie she confronts Cleo again and he calls her a "lying bitch". Soon after Harry learns of the secret relationship and exposes it to the McQueen family at the wedding. Porsche then lets her anger out at Pete and Cleo storms off while [[John Paul McQueen]] ([[James Sutton (actor)|James Sutton]]) threatens to kill Pete. The next day, Jade asks Pete to give her a lift to an old foster home when she believes the Osbornes' don’t want her anymore. Sonia manages to get a message to Jade about Pete being a pervert and Jade bashes a car door on him. Later, Pete is knocked down by [[Darren Osborne]]'s ([[Ashley Taylor Dawson]]) taxi. The next day, it is revealed that Reenie ran Pete over and he threatens to tell the truth if she doesn’t stop pushing Cleo to make a statement to the police. At Christmas, Pete is spying on the McQueen’s where he knows Reenie is on the run, he phones the police as she is planning to leave with Porsche. A few weeks later Pete sends Cleo a text asking to meet up and she goes not realising it is him. Cleo tells Pete that she doesn’t want anything to do with him anymore. Pete then tries to get a job from Nathan Nightingale. Harry confronts Pete for being at the pub working and Pete pretends that Harry attacked him and Jason Roscoe arrests Harry. During the trial, Pete feigned innocence, and it begins to look as if he will go free. However, Cleo takes the stand for a second time and describes what he did to her. Pete is found guilty by the jury; as he is led away to jail, he yells abuse at the McQueen family. Pete returned on October 12 2018, when he is visited in prison by [[Joel Dexter]] (Rory Douglas-Speed) after Cleo's heart attack. Joel warns Pete to stay away from Cleo. He blames Pete for Cleo's purging, but Pete tells Joel that it is in fact Joel's fault. Joel attacks Pete and leaves. ==Reception== When announcing that Pete would stand trial for his crimes, [[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]] described Pete as "sinister". It was said that "fans watched in horror" when Cleo kissed Pete for the first time on-screen. Metro noted that Pete had "weaved a tangled, sinister and destructive web over many months", and has called Pete "sinister and sly" in an article.{{cite web|first=Duncan|last=Lindsay|url=http://metro.co.uk/2016/01/11/hollyoaks-spoilers-paedophile-pete-buchanan-closes-in-on-cleo-mcqueen-again-5616525/|title=Hollyoaks spoilers: paedophile Pete buchanan closes in on Cleo again|work=Metro|date=11 January 2016|accessdate=27 January 2016}} Kai Owen has been nominated for his portrayal of Pete in the long list for Best Actor in the [[Inside Soap Awards]].{{cite web|first=Ian|last=Sandwell|title=Inside Soap Awards 2016 longlist revealed: Which of your soap favourites are up for prizes?|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/eastenders/news/a798505/inside-soap-awards-2016-longlist/ |publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|date=21 June 2016|accessdate=28 June 2016}} ==See also== * [[List of Hollyoaks characters (2015)]] * [[List of soap opera villains]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Hollyoaks}} {{Hollyoaks characters|present}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Buchanan, Pete}} [[Category:Hollyoaks characters]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 2015]] [[Category:Fictional rapists]] [[Category:Fictional pedophiles]] [[Category:Fictional construction workers]] [[Category:Fictional blackmailers]] [[Category:Fictional criminals on soap operas]] [[Category:Fictional domestic abusers]]
